div.p: NEW and CURIOUS OBSERVATIONS On the Art of Curing the Venereal Dieae. And the Accidents that it produces in all its Degrees, explicated by Natural and Mechanical Principles, with the motions, actions and effects of Mercury, and its other Remedies. WHEREIN Are dicovered on the ame Subject the Errours of ome Authors, and the mot notorious Cheats of Empiricks, Mountebanks, and generally of Ignorant Pretenders, and Impotors.
Written in French by Monieur de Blegny, Chirurgeon in Ordinary to the French Queen.
Englihed by Walter Harris, Doctor of Phyick, lately Fellow of New College in Oxford.
With the everal Approbations of the mot Eminent Doctors and Chirurgeons in Paris.
LONDON, Printed for Tho. Dring, over againt the Innertemple-gate; and Tho. Burrel, at the Golden-ball under St. Dunton's Church in Fleet-treet. 1676.

div.head: THE PREFACE.
div.p:
HAving had the happines to be well acquainted with the Ingenious Authour of this Treatie, while I pent ome coniderable time in Paris, in puruance of thoe advantages in Phyick, which are now found there to be very great and extraordinary; by the univeral care, and diffuive munificence of the preent Active Monarch; inomuch that the Curious and Inquiitive of Montpellier, and their other famous Univerities, do now continually flock to Paris, for their better improvement; enjoying not only the pleaure of this Author's good Converation, but the opportunity of his great Practice, in the
Cure of this Dieae; Finding his Principles etablihed, not only by many good Ratiocinations, but econded by much Experience; And being an eye witnes there, how well ucces did anwer his Pretenions, I have thought it not altogether ueles to make England enjoy the ame benefit of thee Obervations, that France did thereby lately receive. And that France did indeed receive ome benefit by this Book, we have reaon enough to believe, if we can trut the Judgment of all the bet Phyicians there. For hardly hath Book been favoured with more numerous Approbations of Learned and Able men. The mot Famous Faculty of Paris was pleaed to attet the uefulnes of it, though I believe no Univerity in the World is more cautious of admitting or approving
New Principles, or New Practice in Phyick: None can keep cloer to the Ancient Long-experienced Method than they. The King's firt and chief Phyician, the chief Phyicians of the Prince of Condè, and of Madam, the everal Chirurgeons alo of the Royal Families, and mot eminent ones in Paris did all agree to put their Names to it, for to tetifie their particular approbation of this Book, and the great Uefulnes of thee Obervations. 'Twill therefore need no Rhetorick to recommend it to the Publick; the lamentable Practice, to ay no wore, that is here commonly ued in the Cure of this Dieae, by many who do acquire themelves a Reputation by nothing ele but good tore of Confidence, will ufficiently convince thoe that read and undertand it, of what conequence
it may prove to the better performance of their undertakings.

I know that the Author nevertheles, before the publick appearance of this Work, whilt his Deign was the Subject of men's ill-grounded Dicoures, wanted not enemies in abundance to cenure & decry him; thoe who were Maters in the Mytery, and had long and weetly tated the pleaant fruits, and plentiful rewards of men's unhappines and debauchery, became preently apprehenive; thought there was Treachery in the cae; and endeavoured to villifie the thing and peron too, as much as they were able, 'till the Pres had cleared, or detroyed all their Jealouies.

Now the ame exceptions may be made againt its appearance in Englih, many may perhaps hrink, and fear ome diminution of their
livelihood; others may indeed plead againt our thus expoing the foundation of this, as well as other parts of Phyick, to the mall undertanding of every Good Woman or illiterate pretender. The firt mut only be pitied, for that they build their Fortunes only on the Ignorance of others; but the latter may deerve a more ample conideration. For many Sober and Learned men have been of the opinion, that our thus dicovering all parts of Phyick in the Language of every Goip, is far from being beneficial to the publick; that we hereby put edged tools into the hands of Children, and teach men to play too much with their own and others Healths.

But if we well conider what the mot eminent Phyicians in former Ages did in this matter, we hall
quickly diipate uch groundles fears, and reconcile our opinions to this Condecention to the meanet Capacities. Hippocrates, Galen, Celus, and others, both Greek and Latine Oracles in Phyick, did always write their works in Greek and Latine, becaue thoe were the Mother-languages of their Countreys; and their Deign was really to do their Countreys good. How eaily do men grant, that every Good, the more it is communicated, the better it is! And certainly that man doth effectually do more good, who makes his labours conduce to the benefit of the Generality, than he who deires to be Admired only in the Cloets of Contemplative men, or the Schools of an Univerity. The Honet Improvers of Husbandry, and Mechanicks, were the men Deified heretofore, and
that will till deerve Immortal Honour in all future Ages. Apollo could never procure that Favour for a man's being skill'd in Languages, or for the mot admired Theories, that were ueles, or little beneficial.

And it is for this reaon that I can never enough admire the truly Noble Deigns of our Royal Society, who do not loe their time in untying frivolous Knots, and unfolding intricate Riddles: They take as large a propect into Univeral Nature, as the Dioptricks of Man's Weak Undertanding will give leave; and though the Subject of their Diquiition eems ometimes low and mean, yet their end is always Noble and Great, and adorned with all the advantages that can be deired. I know giddy heads, and frothy pirits do often make
this Royal Aembly the port of their little Wits, and the mockery of uch as have as little undertanding as themelves; but they may know, that long after their poor hearts are quite knaw'd with Envy, and become the proper food of Worms, this Augut Society will remain the Admiration of all Wie men, and the Glory of this Nation.

It is not a little Obervable, that the Ingenious Members of it have unanimouly choen to write their Works in Englih; and though they convere or correpond with all parts of the World, yet they chue to confine a little to us their vat Dicoveries, and mot coniderable Improvements of Knowledg; which hews, they had rather do much real good at home, than make Otentation of Learning and gain Reputation abroad.

Now notwithtanding what hath been aid on this Subject, though Galen and Hippocrates did communicate their great Widom in their plainet Language, and the mot Ingenious of this Age do o now, yet this mut not be an encouragement for preumptuous perons to think themelves hereby grow wie on a udden, or that the reading of this Book, will ufficiently enable Ignorant men to become Bold Undertakers. They are very much mitaken, who think the printing of an Englih Dipenatory (as hath been of late years indeed done, but with the needles Additions of the mot uncouth and illy Drollery, that ever Learned men have had the ill fortune to be abued in, and this by one who thought himelf, forooth, abundance wier than o deervedly renowned a College, but
mut expect to be thought o only in ome poor Chimney-corners, and over the Winter-tales of ome few harmles deluded people, who mut be pitied as well as himelf) 'tis not uch a buines, I ay, that can et up Good women for the Practiing of Phyick. Much weat, and many great Advantages, both Inward and Outward, God knows, are required to the right performing o weighty an employment. The mot exquiite Fabrick in the Univere, or the Anatomy of the Microcom, mut be throughly undertood; the mot profound Principles of this Art mut be maturely conidered, and well digeted in the undertanding; the Nature of Dieaes, their everal Motions, and different Symptoms, be diligently earched into, either through thoe great aitances men uually meet with in
other Countreys in all manner of repects, or the particular Introduction of ome Friend here at home; the pacious Field of the Materia Medica, mut be often walk'd into, the many curious productions of Nature known, and the excellent Compoitions that Art abundantly furnihes us with, mut deerve Good Conideration.

If thee things were but indifferently weighed, and the evere Obligations that lye on every Honet man's Concience, to the right performing what he undertakes of this high nature, were but a little oberly thought on, it might be able to deter many from o preumptuouly venturing on the lives of others; and turning Mountebanks, with a few Receipts. It is a ad and bleeding reflection, what infinite michiefs, and frequent Murthers are
daily committed in this Great City, by thoe who lily lurk in corners, or ele, who impudently pate their eneles pretenions in all the publick, but tinking places of the Town. And indeed it is a thouand pities, that Able men had not more commonly a Declared Honety, and Known readines to upply the wants of the Multitude; who find themelves in a manner contrained through the Pride and Avarice of ome, and the Lazines of others, to commit the mot precious of all Temporal Bleings, their Health, into the Merciles Hands, and Dangerous Experiments of uch unufferable Enemies to the Publick Good. But the College now intends in a hort time to prevent the encreae or continuance of thee unhappy michiefs, by their particular Care and Charity; and they may
thereby expect more bleing from Heaven on their daily endeavours. For let prophane Bravo's, or conceited Naturalits, coff, or mile, at the particular Dependence I preume every man's Health and Affairs certainly have on the Influence, and Providence of Heaven above us; if they will but eriouly glance into the Hitory of their own pat actions, and the mot important events of their lives, they'll be eaily confounded at their former folly, and ufficiently convinced of the the truth of what I aert.

Thoe therefore who love their Healths in earnet, & do not place it in the reach of Univeral Pills, High-named Elixirs, and upected Arcanums, may be further pleaed to know that Man's Body is a Machine of o very curious a Nature, that its Dieaes and Infirmities are
capable of as great variety of circumtances and alterations, as there are infinity of different parts in it; that ince Luxury and eae have o far prevailed upon us, as to render us uncapable of enduring thoe hardhips little Cottages do till uffer, and thereby receive the benefit of; ince there is uch variety of circumtances in our everal ways of living, and o great an incontancy both in the quaility and quantity of what we eat and drink, Dieaes even of the ame kind mut needs have a very great Latitude, not only in different perons, according to their everal Contitutions, but even in the ame peron at different times.

Nature doth ufficiently declare the truth of this in the various configuration of men's Faces; for eeing there is o great curioity hewn
in the outward contexture of o mall dimenions, that not two perons in all the World can ever be found exactly alike, if they are cloely compared together; what may we then think, or how many little intruments mut we imagine requiite within us, for the orderly motion of the whole Mas! We have no reaon therefore to wonder, that not only different Nations, but alo particular perons, we are once acquainted with, may be eaily known, or ditinguihed by their outward Get, and particular Martch becaue the ubtil diverity of their infinite little Organs, and various dipoition of the whole Fabrick, mut needs incline them to very different motions.

I hall not endeavour to fore-tall you with any Collection of the mot coniderable Remarks of this
Book. A very little Patience will be able to conquer them all. Only I hall take notice to you, that he makes the Pox to be as Ancient as Fornication and Adultery; that wanton men in the days of Old were the Fathers of it, and Harlotry its Mother, when and whereoever Beatlines and Uncleannes have much prevailed on the practice of men. The Confuion and Corruption of o pretious a ubtance as is the Seed, is here uppoed to degenerate into o high a malignancy, when the Seed of many different perons do meet together in the Womb, are there cherihed by the natural heat, and at length exert their acttivities in this heterogeneous Fermentation and we may the eaier conceive the truth of this, if we conider what trange and dimall effects, how
numerous and dreadful Dieaes the Womb is often the Mother of, by Corruption of the Seed in one Woman alone; how much more exalted then mut the putrefaction be, and the unhappy Parent of how degenerate an Off-pring, when the additional ucceions of many new Corruptions do till conpire to the ame end, and till contribute to a further Advancement!

Now though this and everal other things here, are very prettily conceived, and have my entire approbation of them, yet I would by no means be thought implicitely to embrace whatoever is here etablihed, or at random defend all the delights of his thoughts, the cattered productions of his, or any man's wandering Fancy. Every man hath his roving, as well as lucid intervals; and though they may
very often be in the right, yet they may ometimes be in the wrong too. We have all indeed our particular Talents, and it will be certainly required of us, how we have employed or advanced them. It will not be enough for us luggihly to ay, we have had uch or uch a Learned Mater, and carefully laid up the Treaure he committed to our charge, unles ome improvement be made of it, or at leat we hew our endeavours to make an encreae. I am very confident, nothing in all the World hath ever put o coniderable a top to the ucceive career, true Science would daily make, as a blind Suffrage, and mean ubmiion to the dictates of perons we have a good opinion of. And for this reaon I cannot but commend, and admire the declared deigns of ome Worthy men among us; who, though
they do not tranact Wonders every Month, and hew themelves Choen Sons of Nature, yet ure they deerve good words at leat, and that Petulancy, with which ome do daily nibble at them, might methinks be well pared. But to return again; as I do not profes my elf a Diciple of this Gentleman, in all things he is pleaed to utter; o I cannot but give him his due, and commend him much for his ingenious Attempts. For whether Mercury be of uch abolute importance to the cure of this Dieae, when Fermented a while in the Blood, and grown a little inveterate, as this Author would have it; or whether the Ceremony of omiion of a Flux in ome perons of Quality, and epecially Women, be not the True and Latent Caue of their continual Indipoitions, I
leave to every man to judge by his own Dicretion and Experience. For my part, as I do not aent to thoe who violently maintain, that nothing at all can be done without Mercury; o I much pity the poor Spirit of thoe who think of it as a Hobgoblin; and are as apprehenive of giving or receiving the adminitration of it, as they would be of meeting a hungry Lyon. Men ought indeed to be Wonderful Cautious, how they preume to make ue of o upected a Medicine; yet he hath een but little into the Nature of things, or is wholly involved in a popular prejudice, who knows not, that Quickilver, as quick as it is, may be tamed by Art; and may ometimes, by Dicreet Maters, be very eaonably employed to good purpoe. I know 'tis very hard to peak of this
ubject without being mitaken, on without being thought to have too great a kindnes for it, if one doth not utterly Declare War againt all who magnifie its effects: Nevertheles, I am ure all knowing men will interpret what I have now aid, favourably enough.

There's a famous Doctor in Paris, one of the King's Profeors of Phyick, but one who can never hear peak of Mercury, without preently reckoning up twenty Mortal Dieaes it mut needs be apt to produce: This peron hath told me, when I took occaion to peak of the Salivation, that he hath performed a Flux before ome Doctors of his Faculty, without the aitance, or ue of Mercury; and that he mixed the Ingredients, and gave them the Patient faithfully before their faces. The truth of it is, I had o
little Faith in the poibility of raiing a Flux, or at leat a ufficient one, without Mercury; and had o much condecention, as rather to ubmit with a complacent nod, than offer to dipute o coniderable, and perhaps beloved an aeveration, that I had not curioity enough to enquire the manner how it could be done, though I know the peron to be the greatet enemy in the World to uch things as Secrets. But I am apt to believe, that thoe Mortal Dieaes he o zealouly Fathers upon Mercury, do rather arie from the indicreet ue of it, and gros abue that is eaily made of o Active a Medicine; when Quacks or Ignorants boldly take it into their hands.

Whatoever is the Nature, and how dangerous or beneficial oever are the effects of Mercury, certainly the Author of thee Obervations
hath made a fair progree towards the clear Explication of its various Activities; and deerves to be commended for o coniderable a Deign. If the French are able to begin well, & lead the way with Courage, our Englih, I am ure, can not only do the ame, but be very ueful to them, in a brave proecution of what they undertake. Let the French with their nimble Fanies tart, and Invent things ometimes; the olid Judgment of an Englih man is required, to bring them to a due Perfection. As particular perons, o particular Kingdoms have their peculiar Genius & Abilities; we mut, and ought to ait one another with our Communications. One man's head is not big enough to comprehend, or ufficiently contain the vat extent of the Great, or Infinite Curioities of
the Little World. And the neceity of this mutual correpondence, and free intelligence among men, epecially of different Countreys, (whereby Envy and Jealouie are not able to breed the Poyon, they uually do upon the ame pot) puts me in mind of thoe Advantages a Traveller may therefore meet with in Forreign Countreys, more than the Natives themelves are capacitated to enjoy. For if he be not too raw and young, he hall eaily gain admittance into the Cloets of their mot Ingenious men: all the Rarities they pretend to, and Obervations they have made, will be dicovered by them, 'tis doubtful whether with more Ambition, of Delight. Latly, all their Arcanums, and cloe Reerves of Knowledge, hall with a light Promie of ilence, while among them, be ubmitted
to his open view. The truth of what I now ay, I have indeed experimented more than I could any way pretend to, from everal Ingenious perons abroad, and particularly from the Worthy Author of this preent Treatie; into whoe Houe, I had a long time free acces; there to ee the everal Degrees of the POX treated not Speculatively, but Practically, according to the different Progres it uually makes.

div.head: The Approbations of the Chief Phyicians of the Royal Family.

div.p: I nderwritten, Counellor of the King in his Counels, Chief Phyician of his Majesty, do Certifie; that I have read and examined the Book of Monieur de Blegny, treating of Venereal Dieaes; in which I have found his Principles well establihed, his Therapeutick part very Methodical, and his Obervations Good, Curious, and uch as mut needs be very ueful to the Publick.

I nderwritten, Chief Phyician of the Queen of Sueden, and the Prince of Condè; do Certifie, that I have read and examined the Book of Monieur de Blegny, containing many exact and ueful Obervations, from which he draws good conequences for the Knowledge and Cure of the Venereal Dieae; his Reaonings are very clear, the whole Work is very olid, and Experience does confirm it: So that I cannot but tetifie my Approbation of this Book.

closer.dateline: At Paris, this 20th. day of May, 1674.

div.p: I nder-written, Doctor of Phyick, Counellor of the King, Phyician in Ordinary to his Majety, and chief Phyician of Madam, do certifie unto all to whom it may appertain, that the New and Curious Obervations made by Monieur de Blegny, the Queen's Chirurgeon, on The Art of curing Venereal Dieaes; are very advantageous for all uch as are afflicted with them; and do contain the mot aured means of curing them.

div.head: The Approbation of the Dean, and Doctors, deputed by the Faculty of Phyick of the Univerity of Paris, for the Examination of this Book.
div.p:
WE under-written, Dean and Doctors of the Faculty of Phyick, of the niverity of Paris; after having heard the Relation of Dr. Philibert Moriett, Antony Morand, Francis Gouell, and Antony St. Yon, Doctors of the ame Faculty, Commiioned
and Deputed, for reading and examining the Book entituled Obervations on the Art of Curing Venereal Dieaes, compoed by Nicholas de Blegny, the Queens Chyrurgeon; who ubmitted it to the judgment of the aid Faculty: do conent to the Printing of this Book: And though it etablihes the Caue of the POX upon Principles wholly New; yet we have not found any thing in his Method of curing, that is not conformable to ancient received Maxims: and we conceive, that the New Obervations which it doth contain, will erve to encreae an emulation for the future, towards a more diligent earch of the truth of things les known. In tetimony whereof, we have igned.

div.head: The Approbations of the Chyrurgeons of the Royal Families.

div.p:
I nder-written, Chyrurgeon of Monieur, the Kings only Brother, Duke of Orleans; do certifie, that I have read and examined
a Book entituled, New and Curious Obervations, on the Art of Curing Venereal Maladies; in which I have found nothing contrary to the true Method of curing them.

I nder-written, Chyrurgeon in Ordinary to the deceaed Duke of Orleans, and Syndick of the Chyrurgeons of the Royal Families; do certifie, that I have read the Book of New and Curious Obervations of Monieur de Blegny: In which I find the Principles very olidly establihed, and conformable to Experience; o that it cannot but be very ueful, both to uch as are infected with the Venereal Dieae, as well as thoe who undertake the Cure of it.

div.head: The Approbations of the Sworn Mater Chyrurgeons of Paris.

div.p:
I nder-written, Mater, and ancient Provost, and worn Guardian of the Company of worn Chyrurgeons of the City of Paris;
do certifie, that I have read and examined a Book entituled, New and Curious Obervations on the Art to cure Venereal Dieaes, compoed by Nicholas de Blegny; Chyrurgeon in Ordinary to the Queen; in which I have found his Principles well etablihed, his Therapeutick part very Methodical, and his Obervations Curious and eful to the Publick. In Tetimony whereof, I have igned the preent Approbation.

I nder-written, worn Mater Chyrurgeon at Paris, and the Chyrurgeon in Ordinary to the Hopital General; do certifie, that I have read and examined the Book of Monieur de Blegny, the Queen's Chyrurgeon; in which I have found his Principles well establihed, his Method of Practice very ure, and his Obervations good, curious, and ueful for the knowledge and cure of Venereal Dieaes. In tetimony whereof, I have igned this preent Approbation.

closer.dateline: Dated at Paris, the 28th. of May. 1674.

div.head: NEW and CURIOUS OBSERVATIONS On the Art to Cure THE VENEREAL DISEASE, And the Accidents that it produces in all its Degrees.
SECT. 1. In which ome ueful Reflections and Obervations are made on the Names, Defininition, Origine, Caues, Differences, Signs, and prognotick of the Pox.
CHAP. I. Of the Pox in general.

argument.p: 1. Of its different Names. 2. Of its Definition. 3. Of its Origine.

div.p:
1. AMONG all the Dieaes which afflict mankind, it is remarkable that none hath ever received more different Names, than this of which I am going to treat.
All Nations that have marted under it have reciprocally endeavour'd to reproach one another with its Origine, or at leat with its Communication; and every one in particular hath betowed the Name of it on that which was eteemed an uual enemy. Whence it comes to pas that our Europeans have been pleaed to call it American, Spanih, Neapolitan, Italian, and French. Good men have given it the Name of the Shameful Dieae, to render it the more odious unto all, or becaue it hath really omewhat infamous in it, and is the mark as well as the fruit of Debauchery and lubricity. The Poets have given it the Name of Siphilis, becaue they have pretended a Shepherd of that Name was firt infected with it. But it is now generally known in this part of the World under the Names of the Venereal Dieae, or the Pox, by reaon that the parts which are ubmitted to the influences of Venus have heretofore erved for its Origine, and do now more often than any others erve for its Communication; and becaue it very often produces pots and putules on the skin, which are commonly uppoed to be like thoe of the Small Pox, though in good
truth they have no imilitude at all.

2. But if there appears uch difficulty in giving it a proper Name that may be univerally received, it will prove much more difficult to define it with all the neceary circumtances to a regular Definition, by reaon it is o obvious to remark in its form almot all the kinds of Dieaes that Phyicians ue to peak of; or rather indeed becaue all the Accidents it produces are not able to furnih us with one Eential Difference, they reembling many others which nevertheles have Caues very different from that of this Dieae. Wherefore the Definition that you'l here meet with is properly one of thoe that may be called imply Accidental, or a Decription.

The Pox is a contagious Ditemper occaioned by Contact, and by means of a Venemous Salt, proceeding from the mixture and corruption of the Seeds of divers perons, received and contained in the wombs of publick Women; by which all the liquid ubtances wherein it mixes do thicken and corrupt the nerves, skin, and in general the fleh to which it adheres, become prickt, gnaw'd, and dry; latly the bones and cartilages that it
penetrates, do rie up, rot, and corrupt.

Some will perhaps ay, that it might have been more exactly defined by a more comprehenive Genus than Ditemper, ince the olution of Continuity, and a bad Conformation do accompany it almot at all times; nay and that of Affection againt Nature, which I might have choen too, may eem to do better, but indeed would not have determined it o preciely. For Ditemper is abolutely Eential to this Dieae, whereas divers Examples may be given, which do prove it may ubit without olution of Continuity, or a bad Conformation, and conequently they ought not to be conidered but as eparable Accidents.

Now though this Definition be a very long one, yet there is but little need of any ample explication. For though I do remark, for example, that the Pox is contagious by Contact, there is no neceity of troubling you with the proof of this Truth, becaue it is ufficiently known to Phyicians, and the mot part of other Men; Again it may be eaily remarked that the Venereal Matter is a Venemous Salt, only by making ome reflections on the effects which do reult
from its mixture, adhaeion, or penetration; And latly it may be eaily undertood that this Salt is partly Fixt, having the quality of Acids, and partly Volatile, as having that of Poions. It hould now remain to hew you how it can originarily proceed from the mixture and corruption of the Seeds of divers perons. But eeing this matter will be fully explicated in the following Chapter, peaking of the caues of this Dieae, I'll ay nothing more particularly of it here to avoid needles repetitions; Let it uffice to tell you by the by, that the principles which it contains are as probable as new, that they do agree throughout with the following Obervations, and that they conequently ought to be well undertood by thoe who are deirous to receive profit from them.

3. As for, the Origine, or firt begining of the Pox, nothing hath been ever canvaed with more heat, and differences of opinion by the Authors who have written of it; ome have maintained that it was an effect of God's Judgment on Men, and that the ource of it was to be ought only in the punihment that Men had drawn on themelves by the Debaucheries
of the lat Age; Others have drawn it from the Indians, Spain, Naples, and other places, from whence they tell us it was not long ince brought; Some have propoed the carnal copulation of a Leper and a Strumpet, or the conjunction of a Man with a mangy Beat; and others alo have had particular Opinions on this ubject, which we have reaon to believe have as little truth in them, as thoe I have already hinted at, becaue all of them are either Theological or Fabulous, and conequently out of the conideration of Phyicians, who ought to have for their End nothing ele but the conervation of the Nature of Man, conidered imply as a reaonable Creature; or ele the detruction of what is contrary to it: Wherefore it may be aid that they ought not to ue any other means to attain this end, but only uch as are purely Natural, and that they hould not draw their Knowledges and Maximes but from things enibly known.

In truth, if Natural Philoophy erv's for a Bais and Foundation to Phyick, ought not Phyicians to demontrate all things that depend on it, by the principles of Nature, or of Art that imitates
Nature? And is not it very fit to leave Divines the conideration of whatoever is Supernatural, and alo to the Poets by the ame reaon, all things feigned, Chimerical, and uppoed? That we may the better oberve the Rules now mentioned, and atisfy Reaon it elf, by earching into the Origine, Caues, and Remedies of all Dieaes, in the true Agents that have produced them, or may be able to detroy them: that is to ay, in whatoever caues the diminution, depravation, or abolition of Natural Motions, or ele in the Medicaments that can correct their Defaults; for otherwie we mut be obliged to acknowledge Cures that are Miraculous, Magical, or Supertitious for the Effects of Phyick.

Moreover eeing the true Origine of the Pox is the ame with that of its Matter, & that hall not be particularly proved till the following Chapter, for the reaon before marked, it eems the Reader mut be ent thither to learn the account of it: Nevertheles as there have been at all times debauched Women, who have protituted themelves indifferently to all orts of Men, it may here be oberved by way of proviion that the
Pox is almot as ancient as the World, and that its Origine ought to be drawn from the Impurity of the firt Ages, in which it was but little les common than in the preent times we live in; ince the mot ancient Phyicians have poken of all the Accidens that it produces, as well as other Indipoitions that were then common & familiar, and that they have known them as well as wee, under the Names of Heat of Urine, Gonorrheas, Virulent Ulcers, impure Buboes, dry Putules, Tetters, Warts, and latly Nodes, and rottennes of the Bones.

We may alo conceive that the ettled inveterate Leproie, which they peak of as a Dieae very rare and incurable, was what we now call Leproie, and that the other pecies of imple Leproies, which they have mentioned as very common, were the different impreions that Venereal Salts made upon the skin; ince they were accompanied with the greatet part of the other Accidents of the Pox, and that they were cured by the application of Mercurial Oyntments, which we now make ue of to anoint and cure thoe that are infected with the Pox.

But it is very likely, that the regularity which our Fore-fathers oberved in their way of living, did render it more rare, and les apparent, than it is now adayes: As alo it may be believed by the ame reaon, that the brutality of the Indians hath render'd them the more ubject to it, and that the extreme heat they uffer in mot places they inhabit, renders its Accidents more terrible, and apparent, by making the Blood boil more violently.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Caues of the Pox.

argument.p: 1. Reflections on the Diviions of ome Authors. 2. Diviion of the Caues of the Pox, and a Dicoure of its Generation. 3. A remarkable Obervation on the ame ubject. 4. Divers neceary Obervations on the caue of its Communication.

div.p:
1. THoe who depie common Expreions, and affect to ue terms extraordinary and unknown, to cat (as they ay) dut into the eyes of their
Readers, divide the Caues of Dieaes into Occult and Manifet, Sympathick and Antipathick, in a word into Agents and Patients, to which they alo often add by way of ubdiviion, thoe which they pretend Efficient, Material, Formal, and Final; Primitive, Antecedent, and Conjunctive; Near, and Remote; Internal, and External. Nay ome Authors eem to train themelves to divide things that appear indiviible. Nevertheles it is oberved, that thee orts of Diviions have no other profit, but to plung the minds of Men into confuion, into ignorance and obcurity, though they are, or ought to be taught with the deign of intruction. An Example of this truth may be een in the greatet part of young Students, who often employ a coniderable time to learn things that are either unueful, or of which they are not able to give any reaon, whether it be that they do not undertand them, or that they are really inconceiveable, and thoe who write of them have not been able themelves to conceive them.

2. But that we may not fall into the like inconvenience, and to enlighten the matter I treat of, as much as it is capable,
I hall conider but only two Caues of the Pox; to wit, that of its Generation, which conits in the Mixture and Corruption of the Seeds of divers perons, received and retained in the ame Womb; And that of its Communication, which conits in the contact of impure Perons.

It is o much the more neceary to prove the poibility of the former, as it is a new Opinion, that will conequently be pretended fale by thoe who admit no Novelties at all: And I fear alo that Reaon and Experience do not furnih us with proofs clear enough, to dicover this truth before the eyes of Opiniators, that love rather to follow blindly what they conceive through prejudice, than take the pains to examine things, to ditinguih rightly the true from the fale.

'Tis after this manner I reaon on this Subject. Philoophers, and generally the Learned, do acknowledge no coniderable change in Nature, that is not made by a fermentation; of which no caue is found more evident than the motion and action of contrary Bodies: An Example of this truth, which may particularly erve for a proof of my Opinion, is oberved in the Generation of perfect Animals,
and principally in that of Man; for the Seeds of which he is generated do contain not only the Idea and Form of all the parts, but alo the good and ill Qualities, the Temperaments, and Natural Inclinations of thoe from whom they are emitted; and this is o true, that the particles which convey thee powers, act one upon the other, after the Conception; and that Infants of the ame Family are ometimes Male, ometimes Female, now like Father, another time like the Mother, and often partly like one, and partly like the other.

Now if it be true to ay, that the different qualities which are found in the Seeds of only two perons may be agitated o coniderably, as to caue one to over-rule the other, whilet they are contained in the Womb, for Generation; that of a third peron, which is there received a little afterwards, may be lookt upon as a matter extraordinary, which mut hinder Generation, or at leat render it imperfect, by a more unequal mixture, and tronger agitation; this erves to perwade me that Moles in Women may be as well the effects of Cuckolding, or Adultery as the production of Imagination;
ince it is known beides, that the bet Anatomits do eteem great quantity of Mentrual Blood (which is notwithtanding another principle of Generation) for one caue of this confuion and diorder: To which may be added, that it is by reaon of this Confuion that common Strumpets never conceive at all, though they often do the ame with thoe that have Children, & perhaps alo with more advantageous circumtances; becaue the different Seeds that they receive, do caue a more vehement and irregular fermentation, as they come from abundance of perons, and are filled with a great many contrary and oppoite particles; from which fermentation there mut conequently proceed a very bad change, and further from Perfection, to which Nature doth always tend. On this ubject it may further be oberved, that Corruption is the change, which follows fermentations that are abolutely againt Nature; and it is eaily to conceive, how thoe Seeds being mixed together, may pas from their fermentation to corruption, almot at one and the ame time, ince this mixture doth render them improper for their Natural Ue, and that
the heat and moiture of the part which contains them, do quickly dipoe them to be corrupted. Now the mot important thing that remains on this ubject, is to let you ee, how they can become Venemous, that is to ay, ubtile, penetrant, and proper to coagulate and corrupt the Blood, as other Poions do. But as the Seed is generally acknowledged for the bet part of our Blood, and every body knows, that Corruption is o much the wore, as the matters corrupted were more pure and delicate before; It eems that this truth is ufficiently proved of it elf, and that there is no neceity of earching Reaons more trong or convincing to utain it. Nevertheles if we reflect on the great tore of Spirits wherewith all the Seed is filled, and on the quality of the Part that receives them; we hall then ee that there is no matter which can remain more Spirituous, and conequently more Venomous after its Corruption; becaue there is none better tor'd with Spirits, nor any more diligently preerved; this change being made in the Womb, which is a part Naturally dipoed to receive the Seed, and conerve all the parts of it: And what is
till obervable, is that in paing from its Natural ubject into other ubjects, it becomes o much the more Venemous, as it hath paed a greater number of new Fermentations.

3. Furthermore, we may ay of this Opinion, that it is one of thoe that cannot well, be proved by any other way but our Reaon, and that it is almot impoible to find ubjects, on which Experiments ufficiently ure and undoubted may be made; for beides that the Pox doth not always appear, and that there are but few perons who may be believed abolutely pure and clear from it, there mut therefore remain but few indeed who can be eteemed proper for uch an Experiment. Nevertheles I hall here report an Obervation, that meer chance was the caue of to one of my Friends, and which may alo erve to prove my thoughts on this ubject.

Though this Obervation eems to be accompanied with all the Accidents that can be deired, to maintain my Opinion, yet I do not pretend to make it pas for a thing altogether unquetionable; both for that it is poible to be fale, and becaue there might have been ome unknown Abues under equal and as good appearances, I therefore leave all curious perons the liberty of making what other Experiments they pleae, and to every one in particular that of judging the other circumtances of this Opinion, according to their own Ideas, or particular Obervations, as things Problematical, and no way abolutely neceary to the Art of curing the Pox.

4. After having ufficiently explicated what I mean by the Original Caue or Generative of the Pox, it is now neceary to oberve the everal orts of Contact, that can conduce to its Communication, & which are here conidered as
Caues of this Dieae, becaue it is by them principally gained.

But we mut not imagine that this econd Caue is always found in Coition, as the firt; it matters not after what manner the Contact is made, provided that it permits an adheion or entrance to ome part of the Venereal matter; it may be made either directly or indirectly, and here's an Example of it: A Woman with Child, who in the Company of one that hath the Pox, hall attract into her Womb, the corrupted Seed that hall be there ejaculated, will catch the Pox immediatly, by reaon of the Coition and Contact that preceded; and the Infant that hall be in her Womb, will be alo infected with it, by reaon of the ame Coition, but not by reaon of the Contact, becaue the remotenes of the Infant hinder'd the Infection from being direct in repect of it. The ame thing may be aid of Infants that are engendered of divers like Seeds, according to the ordinary coure of Nature, or by way of Superfetation.

Beides the Example that I jut now gave, many other orts of Contacts may be found, which are made by other ways,
and yet fail not to caue the Pox: For Example, if one hould happen to drink after him that hath the Pox, and by chance put the Lips to the ame place of the Glas, where ome little Poion of the Ulcers of his mouth, or ele ome of his pittle fill'd with Venereal Salts, hall have tuck; it often happens, that this either caues other Ulcers, by uperficially adhering to the parts, or ele without delay the univeral Pox; when the Salt that they contain is volatil and penetrant enough to enter into the Veins and Arteries, without leaving any marks of its paage; for let ever o little of it be once mixt with the Blood, it will work like Leaven in a great deal of Dough, or rather it ferments and corrupts as other Poions do, which are always more pernicious by their quality, than by their quantity.

Another Example of this nature may be drawn from thoe who are infected with this Dieae, for having unfortunately lain in the heets, wherein one in the Pox had weated, or in which there might remain ome of the matter that run from his Ulcers.

Beides thee orts of Contact, all others
may be aid to be immediate, becaue they are made by the application of one part againt another: Among them all the mot ordinary is Coition, becaue this Dieae doth for the mot part begin in the parts that erve for Generation, and its matter is not always dipered univerally through the Body: In this action, if a Man hath Venereal Ulcers on his Yard, ome part of the Poion that nourihes them, and which is nothing ele but a diolution of the Salts that contitute the Pox, doth almot always tick in ome part of the Womb, or ele in the wrinkles of the neck of her Womb, that he lies with, wherein he often caues other Ulcers, by adhering to the skin, or pellicules that cover thoe parts; on which matter it may be oberved, that I have jut reaon to add this lat circumtance, by reaon that this matter doth not always necearily adhere in Women, either becaue the Membrane that covers the Vagina, is very mooth, polihed, and cover'd with a limy Humour, or becaue the Seed that is therein ejaculated doth often lide out at the ame time, and carries away with it this Virulent matter o much the more eaily, as it hath not
had time to adhere, and as the cituation and form of this part do much contribute to its eaier liding out; it is alo for this reaon that common Strumpets do ometimes give hurt to others, though they have none at all themelves; becaue the approaching them a little after they have enjoyed the Company of other men that are impure, doth give ome part of the impurity they received, though themelves may be exempt from any adheion, or effect of the remaining matter, by the means that I have mentioned.

It is obervable that a virulent Clap, and the univeral Pox are able equally to render the Seed impure; in o much that if that of a Man who is infected with it, be attracted and retained in the Womb of a Woman, it may caue in her either a Virulent Clap by adhering particularly to the permatick Veels, or ele the univeral Pox, by paing through the Oririfices of the Arteries and Veins, that terminate in this part. In a word, a Woman that hall uffer uch Indipoitions, may in like manner communicate them to a ound Man, that hall convere with her, by the adheion or entrance of the matter that can caue them.

It is alo oberveable, that the Impurities
of the Mouth of a little Infant that hath the Pox are able to infect the Nure, by adhering to her Teats, or ele the air of his Repiration, that can eaily penetrate them through the pores that give paage to the Milk. In like manner an infected Nure can impart her Dieae to the little One, by an adheion of the matter of her Ulcers, or by the ue of the corrupted Milk that is uckt from her Teats.

To ly with one that hath the Pox, and touch him naked while he weats, or when he hath Ulcers and Putules on his skin, is a thing that may well be believed very dangerous, and chiefly for thoe that have their pores very open, and therefore do eaily receive the impreion of any thing that touches them. The cutom of Kiing with open Mouth, is another very dangerous buines, for the reaons I have poken of. Latly, there are o many different Contacts which are capable of giving the Pox to thoe who have it not, that when you hall once know it auredly by its Signs, you need not trouble your elf but little about the manner how it was communicated, ince you cannot always find it out,
and ince it is often unknown, even to the perons ick themelves.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Differences of the Pox, which may erve to make a Prognotick.

argument.p: 1. An Advertiement on this Subject, and general Diviion of the Degrees; from whence may be drawn ome Differences. 2. Explication of the Differences that the firt Degree furnihes us with, and general diviion of thoe that may be oberved in the econd. 3. What may be undertood by Particular Poxes. 4. What the niveral Pox is. 5. Explication of the differences that may be drawn from the third Degree.

div.p:
1. BEfore I come to peak of the Differences of the Pox, it is good to acquaint you, that I do not conceive any different Species of it, nor own any Sanguine, Cholerick, Phlegmatick, and Melancholick ones, as ome Men have inconiderately
done; but on the contrary do always eteem it as the ame, in what degree, and whatoever ubject it may be found, ince it is always produced by one and the ame caue, that always acts after the ame manner, and produces different Effects according to the various dipoition of the parts that receive its action.

This being once preuppoed, you will eaily grant, that the differences of this dieae can only be drawn from the diverity of its degrees; that is to ay, from the time that its matter hath been received, from the progres that it hath made, and from the Accidents that it produces.

2. Though I conider the time that the Venereal matter hath been received, for one degree, from whence ome differences of the Pox may be drawn; and that ome Authors do think to acertain the Prognotick of it, by the conequences they thence draw; yet it mut be acknowledged that they are of no great conideration. For though it may be aid that this Dieae is either New or Inveterate, according to the more or les time it hath been contracted, yet one cannot judge for all that of the eaines, difficulty,
or impoibility of its Cure: becaue this ame matter is more or les active according to its quality or quantity, or ele according to the particular dipoitions of the Bodies, in which it enters. For 'tis certain, as I have already oberved, that it becomes more Venemous, & conequently more penetrant & ubtile, when it hath had duration in the change that may be made of it from different ubjects; and the great quantity of it doth very much advance the diorder it is able to make, in every particular peron. To which may be added, that it acts the more uddenly, when it is excited by the heat that is found in the Temperaments of Cholerick or Sanguine Bodies, which are o much the more dipoed to uffer its ininuation, as their pores and other paages are naturally more open; but on the contrary it is ometimes o fixt, and hut up in the cold, or gros Humours of Phlegmatick or Melancholick perons, that it can lye there a long time like fire under ahes, and experience lets us ee, that it can lurk 10 or 12 years, before any effects of its Motions will be felt; whence it follows, that the Judgment of the three Circumtances
I related, do chiefly depend on the examination that ought to be made, on the progres it hath already made, and the accidents it hath produced. For by the conideration of the firt circumtance, the Particular or Univeral Pox may be judged of: and this ditinction is of uch importance to the right prognotick of the eaines, or difficulty of its Cure, that it lets us ee, in what degrees particular or common remedies may uffice, or whether the tronger and more general are alo neceary.

3. Before we pas further, it eems very proper to explicate what I mean by this Difference, that I may let you ee how it doth not erve only to ditinguih the degrees of this Dieae, and that it is not any way contrary to what I aid of it at the beginning of this Chapter. I do call then a particular Pox, when its matter doth continue fixt to ome parts, which uffer it to be dreed and cured with particular Remedies, external, or topical; and for which thoe are employed chiefly that are called General, or Internal, as well as to hinder the progres it might make by the penetration of its Salts: uch are, for example, the Venereal
Ulcers and Chancres, or ele Claps, and Virulent Gonorrheas; and which I call the Pox, as well as the others named before, becaue they are all of them productions of an impure Contact, and of ome Venereal matter received; of which all the effects may be oberved, though it doth till adhere to ome particular parts, as well as when it is dipered over all the Body; for the coagulation and corruption that I have aid doth happen by it in the liquid ubtances may be oberved in the Seed that runs in Virulent Gonorrheas, or ele in the fixation of the Juyce that nourihes the parts in which the Venereal Ulcers are, that do by this means degenerate into Chancres, or Carnoities; The pricking, gnawing, or drying up of the Fleh, may be alo oberved in the beginning, augmentation, and changes of thee ame Ulcers; in a word, the elevation, rottennes, and corruption of olid parts are ometimes the conequents of thee firt Evils, when they happen upon Bones or Cartilaginous parts; in o much that you may hence ee with how much reaon I do reckon them for degrees of the Pox, ince it is commonly by then that it is found to
begin, and they are almot never een to advance into a higher degree, when they ar • dret as they ought to be.

I do acknowledge nevertheles, that this name of the Pox was at firt given to this Dieae, only by reaon of the reemblance that was thought to be between it and the Small Pox, through their pots and putules; and it eems conequently, that this Name hould then only belong to it, when it is in the degree that produces them. But we mut oberve, that it often paes from one degree to another, almot inenibly; o that ometimes it cannot properly deerve that Name, if we tick cloe to this Circumtance; beides it may be aid, that Names do not etablih the eence of Dieaes, and it matters not how this Dieae is called, provided that it be conidered as always of one Species according to my opinion.

4. When the Venereal Salts are ubtile enough to penetrate through the pores, without taying in the places through which they pas (as hath been een in ome perons) or rather when they there top, and caue the particular Poxes, of which I have poken, without the perons
taking care notwithtanding to oppoe its ininuation, by the means of fit Remedies that drive or attract from within outwardly; they then caue what I call the univeral Pox, by ininuating into the Veels that contain the Blood, and preading univerally over all the Body, by the Circulation.

They who have read the Authors that write on this ubject, will wonder doubtles that I make the Venereal Salts pas from the uperficial parts into the Veins and Arteries, without peaking of that Species of the Pox they make conit only in ubtile Vapours and Spirits; but, as I have already told you, I cannot acknowledge any different Species of it, and there is no reaon beides, for conidering what they have propoed on this ubject, as one of its degrees, ince it is not at all likely that thee Spirits they pretend infected, are able to circulate about the body, to penetrate the narrowet pores, caue Itchings, Inquietudes, and fall of Hair, the conequences of it, without mixing with the blood, by penetrating the Veels I now poke of which are but too porous for this effect, and are generally dipered into all parts of the body.

5. Moreover it may be aid that the differences which may be drawn from the Accidents the Pox produces, are very coniderable; for it may be aid to be Mobile, during the ebullition of the blood, the diperion and motion of its matter: that is to ay, when it yet caues thoe wandring pains, or other Accidents that appear, and vanih away ucceively one after another; and on the contrary, it may be conidered as in a fixt condition, when this dipered matter doth adhere more particularly to ome parts, out of which it is not able to get neither of it elf, nor by the endeavours that Nature ues, unles econded by proper Remedies, which alo do become ueles, in thoe that have their Internal and Principal parts much injured by the adheion and action of this matter. But as the diperion of it, as well as of all other Humours that are extravaated, is caued mot commonly in the Extremities; the mot familiar Example of this degree may be oberved in thoe that uffer in the night fixt pains of thee ame parts, the elevation and corruption of bones and cartilages. Latly it may be een by what I have aid, that thee differences
are able to furnih us with the mot important conequences for the better making a good Prognotick of the Pox; becaue we can eaily judge that the degree in which its matter continues till in Motion, can be carried off with eaines enough, without leaving any impreion at all of its ill effects; and on the contrary, we may judge it ometimes incurable, where this ame matter is abolutely topt & fixt, becaue it hath made us ee in ome perons all its effects on thoe parts that are neceary to life, and it is alo rarely carried off in thoe I mentioned for the ordinary Example, without leaving the ad marks of its activity: ince it is ometimes impoible to regenerate thoe parts that have been conumed; for Example, the bones, and among others thoe of the Palate & Noe, which are often conumed in this degree, and leave after their entire corruption very coniderable deformities, that can never be repaired.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Judgment of the Pox.

argument.p: 1. Its diviion, and how ignorant Men and Impotors do commit Abues in this Dieae. 2. Many notorious Deceits and Impotures on this ubject. 3. A general diviion of the Signs that make us know this Dieae. 4. Particular diviion of the Symptomes that happen in all its degrees, by the means of which the Prognotick, of it may be auredly made.

div.p: 1. THe Judgment of the Pox conits in knowing its Eence, or Prognoticating (as I have already aid) the eaines, difficulty, or impoibility of its Cure.

The Signs by which thee things may be judged of, are the Symptomes that accompany this Dieae in all its degrees, and are of a very great number, and do therefore deceive ignorant Men, becaue they do not all happen at a time, and Symptomes do often happen that much reemble them, though they are indeed
produced from other caues. This is that which gives, occaion to Impotors to make but ill ue of the credulity of thoe that doubt of the condition they are in, and therefore find themelves engaged in this uncertainty to ask Counel, and require uccour of thoe from whom they in Jutice ought to expect it, if they had but Honety and Charity, which are things very neceary for all uch as do profes Phyick.

The Reaon that I have to peak after this manner •• that the greatet part of thoe who pretend to cure this Dieae now-a-days, do make the mallet appearances pas for undoubted degrees of the Pox, and they do not fear to etablih their Reputation at the cot of thoe who are not wie enough to know their own Folly, and yet have a blind confidence on others o mighty ingenious, as to run the hazard of loing all their Employments, their Etates, and Lives, for to be cured of an imaginary or uppoed Dieae.

Though I have learnt an infinity of Cheats of this nature, by the report of thoe who have come to conult me after others on this ubject, and by what I
have een my elf, by feigning my elf ick, and everal other ways; yet I will not by relating them encreae the bulk of my Book without profit, and I believe it will uffice, to relate ome of the mot remarkable of thee Impotures, to erve for an Advertiement or Warning to thoe who may be for the future in the like perplexities.

2. The greatet part of thoe who think they know the World well, do believe themelves ufficiently aured, if they have ecaped from falling i •• o the hands of Empiricks, and uch as ditribute ecret Remedies; nevertheles it is too true that there are many of thoe who are contrary to this ort of Men, that are not really Honet, but only in appearance, and do indifferently make profit of all the occaions they meet with. This truth is ufficiently known to many curious perons who have feigned themelves to have the Pox, & have found among thoe I poke of perons that love their interet enough to confirm them in this Opinion upon the mallet uppoitions; and I have een my elf by chance that there are ome among them, who do not o much as endeavour to hide their Impotures
by affected appearances, but without any fear make ill ue of the ignorance and eaines of thoe that go to conult them, with a very trange piece of confidence: The tory that I am going to relate may erve o much the better for a proof of what I here affirm, as it happened to a man of good credit, that is now living, and might be able to aert the truth of it. This man came to conult me upon the account of everal hard Putules, that grew over all his skin; Upon this occaion I made all the neceary remarks on his pat Life, his Temperament, the preent condition of his peron, his Wife and Children; and by this examination I knew it was nothing ele but what Phyicians call, the Gnawing or Corroive Herpes, and I therefore propoed to him the ue of a Bath, and other Remedies both general and particular, that ordinarily erve for the cure of this Ditemper. But becaue he was afraid he had the Pox, and people often think they have the misfortunes they are afraid of, he till continued in the apprehenion he was in before, and came to deire me ome few days afterwards to conduct him to ome famous Practitioner, to ee whether he
would joyn his Opinion with mine, that o he might be better aured what to believe of it. To this end I waited on him to a certain peron, whom a fair how of eeming Honety, tore of Riches, and a good Reputation of being an Able man, have auredly placed above the common Rank, but was guilty nevertheles on this occaion of an action altogether unworthy of thoe good qualities; for without giving leaure to the Patient, or my elf, to relate thoe things that the ight cannot dicover, without making any examination at all, and only after a precipitate inpection of thee Putules, he told him it was a very fine ort of Pox, and therefore he had bet preently reolve for a retreat of ix weeks.

Beides thoe that engage credulous perons to uffer the Salivation, when there is no neceity of it, there are alo a great many Mountebanks to be found, who give a fale Judgment of the Pox, and perwade men they have it when they are altogether free. The eaines they have found in perwading men o, hath given them encouragement for another ort of cheating: They caue Billets to be ditributed in mot parts of the Town, and clap up papers in the mot reorted places, nay and ometimes preume to write little Pamphlets, filled with nothing but follies and lyes, wherein they confidently boat that they are able to cure the Pox, without Mercury, without garde, or keeping their Chamber; and they have o much the more eaily found perons who will believe them, and render their Impoture omewhat likely by
their own mitaken Experience, as there are many perons who think themelves ick of this Dieae, when they do really enjoy mot perfect Health. But that which plainly hows us it had not ubited hitherto but only by this means, is that they are known to give the Salivation to thoe they think really in the Pox, for they do then uppoe their Dieae in a degree almot deperate, and they are not able conequently to cure them, but by making ue of this Remedy, which they make pas for the extreme one of all, and do nevertheles very familiarly employ it under this diguie, with uch a conduct as mut always be believed very dangerous, in thoe that have learnt nothing of it but by Receipt.

Though this Impoture be the more common and ordinary of all, yet it mut not be eteem'd the only one, and there are ome among them that do practie another till more remarkable. Whatoever Accidents thoe that have the Pox do uffer, when they addres themelves to thee men, they will always aure them they have no uch thing as the Pox, and o will promie to cure them with uch Remedies as they call pleaant, mild
and inipid, but are always notwithtanding the tronget and mot violent Sudoriicks, Purgatives, and Vomitives, that do extremely exhaut and dry up the body, to make the Accidents ceae, by conuming the eroities that are pred abroad, and are the Caues of them; inomuch that thee Patients find themelves cured in all appearance, till the next ebullition of the Blood begins again, and there happens a new diperion of the matter that is able to produce other Symptomes, which they then make pas for unhappy Relapes, or ele new Dieaes, that mut undergo a new Cure. So that thee perons thus affected do furnih them with continual profit, as Cows with Milk, and a mall number of them will be able to provide them Employment enough.

But among all thoe that impoe on credulous perons, there are none that make ue of a more abominable Stratagem, than thee that follow; for they do endeavour to perwade all their Patients that apply to them for help, that all their bodies are filled with Mercury, or ele with Venereal matter, that mut be driven out as fat as may be, if they
desire to ecape death; and to convince them of the truth of this uppoition, they tell them, they hall preently ee abundance of Impurities come out of their bodies, o oon as ever their Remedies begin to be applied. In effect, as this pretended Remedy is nothing ele but an Oyntment applyed on their skin, that is compounded of Cantharides; this promie of theirs eems true to many men, becaue it raies Bliters full of eroities, that eem to come through their pores, and becaue it makes them Urine prodigiouly, nay often blood it elf, by cauing an inflamation and exulceration of the Bladder, which are mortal Accidents.

3. But after having ufficiently poken of the fale Judgments of Impotors, and the means they make ue of for commiting their Abues, it is time to let you ee what are the true Signs that candid men mut take notice of, for to judge aright of this Dieae.
Thee Signs may be divided into uch as are known to the Patient alone, and uch as are enible both to Patient and Phyician.

The former are the impure Contacts that have preceded this Dieae, the
pains they feel while they Urine, the Inquietudes, and univeral Itchings, the los of Appetite, the indifference for Coition, the Nocturnal pollutions without pleaure, the uppreion of the Terms in Women, or of the regulated Hemorrhoides in ome men: Latly the mobile or fixt pains of the Head, the Shoulders, and Extremities.

The latter Signs are Gonorrheas, Buboes or Poulains, Ulcers, and Chancres of the Yard, and of the Privities of Women; or ele the hardnes that remains after their Cicatrices, the fall of Hair from Head and Beard, the Wounds and Ulcers that cannot be cured with ordinary Remedies, the Tetters, Putules, and Warts; latly the Elevation, Rottenes, and corruption of Bones.

But we mut be ure to oberve that all, or mot of thee Signs that I have named, are but Accidents of the Pox it elf; that it produces not all of them at all times, nor in all ubjects, and that they become different according to its divers degrees; in o much that they do not happen always in a contant and aured Order. For there have been ome perons een, whoe bones have rotted
with the Pox, before ever any of thoe Accidents, Authors do call Antecedent, have been at all felt; which Accidents I had rather call Conequent, becaue they do mot commonly follow thoe that accompany the particular Poxes, of which I have poken. Nevertheles as it is impoible to make a good Prognotick of this Dieae, without being able to ditinguih all the degrees it can happen in, it will be neceary to reflect on all that hath been already aid, to the end we may the better find, how it paes out of one degree into another, and why in each particular one it doth produce very different Symptomes.

4. It may with Reaon be aid, that the Ulcers which are caued by impure Contacts, do contitute the firt degree of the Pox, becaue they are the effect of ome matter that very uperficially adheres; they cannot be ditinguihed from ordinary Ulcers at their beginning, but by the preceding Contact, and the parts in which they happen; and they may be cured in this condition with common and ordinary Deiccatives. But when the Salts that caued them, cannot be detroyed by thee or other means,
they then penetrate into the Veels that contain the blood, or ele mix with the Natural moiture that remains in the ulcer'd part, and fix it in uch manner, that from Ulcers they degenerate into Chancres; and then indeed they are much more dangerous and hard to cure, but are known by the elevation of their white ides, by their obcure colour, and by their hardnes.

You may eaily judge that Claps, or Virulent Gonorrheas, are of a yet higher degree than the Ulcers I now poke of; becaue the matter that makes them is more deeply driven into the bodies of thoe who uffer them, and the parts that are infected with them are uch as are inward and concealed: The Bladder, for Example, and the parts adjacent or dependent on it, are the firt that uffer the Inflammation, which is ufficiently known by the heat and pains that are felt in urining, and ometimes by an entire uppreion of the Urine; the eminal parts, and the Seed it elf are not more free from an Alteration, ince the los, thicknes, & corruption of the Seed, are undoubted marks of it. Latly the paages through which thee Impurities
are carried do not long remain free from their ill effects, but become exulcerated by the harp points of the Salts they contain, and this exulceration doth caue them to uffer very grievous pains, during the paage of their Urine.

While this particular Pox is but newly contracted, it can be cured with a great deal of eae and afety, by preventing that which we ought otherwie to fear, and taking away whatoever appears, by the ue and application of proper Remedies to this effect. But when it hath had a coniderable duration without neceary uccour, it mut be then believed to be of a much more difficult and dangerous Cure, becaue all its Accidents become greater, and the further penetration if its matter, that is, the univeral Pox, may be then with jut Reaon upected. Therefore it mut then be treated with more care and precaution, and the Prognotick that is made of it mut be more doubtful.

We may now oberve that the Venereal Salts do often pas from the parts I poke of into the orifices of the Veins and Arteries, and do ometimes penetrate more directly by the ubtilty & keennes
of their points. Nevertheles what way oever they enter, it is always true, that they caue in ome a great ebullition of their blood, either by the particular dipoitions they find in it, or ele by their own deleterious quality; during which ebullition, the Impurities do eparate, much after the ame manner as Lees do in the fermentation of Wine, and o are driven out after a while by the force of Nature, or, if you will o, by the Faculty Expultrive into the Glandules of the Groins, where it caues a Bubo, or Botch, that erves for a Criis of the Pox, if it be attracted and brought to perfect Suppuration.

It may be ditinguihed from other Tumours, that ometimes happen in thoe parts, by the impure Contact that preceeded it, by the Claps, Gonorrheas, Ulcers, and Chancres, that often happen a little before its dicovery, but principally by its low advancement, its durity, and large Bais.

But this penetration of the Venereal matter into the mas of the blood, is not always attended with o happy ucces as the extruion of uch a Tumour: the Venereal Salts do ometimes participate
more of fixt than volatile, and the blood is not equally hot and ubtile in all orts of men, o that in ome it preently coagulates by this means, much after the ame manner as ome curious perons have experimented, by yringing Acid Liquours into the Veins of Brutes; and this coagulation is often the Caue of thoe uppreions I took notice of, and of their loathing all Meat, a •• of their indifference as to Coition, becaue whil't it continues, the Circulation grows very low, and conequently the Natural Functions that depend on it, become interrupted. Wherefore this time may be oberved for another degree of the Pox, that can nevertheles be clearly carried off, by the inward Sudoriicks, which do diolve and attenuate the blood, by new ebullitions, provided that Nature be alo aited in her other evacuations.

At the time that this coagulation of the blood ceaes, by the eparation of the different particles it then contains, we may conider the beginning of its fermentation, which is performed o much the more gently, and by degrees, as it met before with Obtacles to hinder it; whence it comes to pas that this blood
doth but only rie and boil by little and little, though indeed this gentle ebullition fails not nevertheles to caue Symptomes very much different from thoe I have already poken of, and uch as I hall remark hereafter. For whil't it lats, light vapours arie from it, that are carried all over the body, and do caue thoe inquietudes of mind, and body, thoe Itchings of ••• skin, and fall of the Hair from the Head and Beard.

Wherefore this time may be alo conidered as another degree of the Pox, wherein nevertheles it may be abolutely cured, as well as in the former, by a good ue of ordinary Remedies, or ele by a Critical Motion of ome other Dieae upervening. But as thee means do fail ometimes of the deired effects, it were much better in this condition to provoke a light Salivation, by which a quick, eaie, and aured Cure may be hoped for.

When the fermentation encreaes, or that it is in its height, the Venemous eroities do eparate from the blood, and pas á travers the coats of the Veels that contain it, after which they lide along, the Nerves and Membranes, and caue
thoe wandring pains that are felt now in one part, and now in another; ometimes alo Nature trives to drive them forth through the pores; but as thee eroities are heavy and full of Salts, they adhere to the skin intead of going forth, and there caue Ulcers when they are mixt with ome corrupted matter; or if on the contrary they are chiefly charged with fixt Salts, they there raie putules, that are flat, caly, dry, and of a red drawing towards an Orange colour; or ele if they are fill'd with volatil Salts, they rie omewhat higher, and produce hard Tetters and Warts upon the Yards, privities of Women, the Groin, and other places.

This degree of the Pox is not the mot difficult of all to be cured, but it is known very well by experience that there is nothing but Mercury among Remedies that is able to excite the Criis that can terminate it.

Oftentimes after thee matters have been thus wandring about the body, they altogether adhere and abolutely tay in ome parts, and caue by this means the lat and mot terrible degree of the Pox. For though their adheion doth ometimes
happen only in the Mucles and Periostium, they fail not to caue mot lamentable Accidents, becaue by pricking, gnawing, and continually drying the nervous Fibres of thee parts, they there produce thoe fixt and nocturual pains, ome perons have found inupportable. The Cartilages, and epecially the bones, are alo other parts that uffer great changes by their penetration; for they caue a ort of fermentation in the Marrow or Juyce they contain, by the means of which Tumours are een to happen, that are called Nodes, and which are nothing ele but an elevation of their very ubtance, that is at lat rotted and corrupted by the preence and action of thee Impurities.

Nevertheles though the Pox is very hard to cure, when its matter is thus topt, and unk into the parts I named, it may be oberved that it would be always curable even in this degree, if this ame matter were not ometimes tuck to parts that are till more coniderable. But it hath been unhappily proved in ome Men, that the parts which are called Noble, and thoe that immediately adminiter to the Noble ones have not
been exempt from its activity and cruel effects. Wherefore the Prognotick that may be made of it, is o ad and lamentable, that it always conits in judging the extraordinary difficulty, or ele impoibility of the Cure.

But beides the general Coniderations that I have marked, for making a good Prognotick of the Pox in, all its degrees, there mut be repect had to the particular circumtances of each ubject, as, for example, to the Temperament, Sex, Age, Strength, and alo Employment of him we pretend to cure. For I have known by Experience that the inquietudes which important affairs do give ome men, do heat and inflame the Spirits, and thereby caue the Mercury to enter into the Brain, where it finally caues mot deplorable Accidents.

div.head: SECT. 2. In which neceary Obervations are made on the means to cure the Pox, while it is but Particular; on the Natural and Critical. Motions which do terminate it when it becomes niveral, and on the Medicines which commonly erve to raie the Artificial Criis of it.
CHAP. I. Of the orts of Particular Pox that are called Ulcers and Chancres.

argument.p: 1. Why the particular Poxes are here treated of in the first place, and of the general diviion that may be made of them. 2. Of Venereal lcers in general. 3. The particular Method of curing them. 4. Obervation on the Purges that ought to be employed in their Cure. 5. Of other Preervatives. 6. Divers neceary Obervations on the Remedies that erve for curing them, when they degenerate into Chancres. 7. Of the Phymois and Paraphymois.

div.p:
1. AFter having thus remarked all the general things that I have judged
neceary for the undertanding thoe that more particularly relate to the Art of curing the Pox: It is now time to peak of its Remedies, and the circumtances that mut be oberved for the uing them well and without danger. And eeing the matter that caues the Pox doth in a manner always adhere to ome particular parts, before it advances to infect the whole body; ome Reflections hall here be made in the firt place on the means of curing it, while it doth continue particular, and on the Preervatives that ought to be ued for hindring its becoming Univeral.

But to the end we may avoid ueles Repetitions, I hall ay nothing more in general of particular Poxes, nor of the Reaons for which I have o named them, becaue thee things have been already ufficiently explicated, when I poke of the Differences and Signs, which may erve for the Knowledge and Prognotick of all the degrees of this Dieae. It will uffice to ay here, that they maay be divided into uch as appear only in the parts that may be een and touched, and into uch as happen in other parts that our enes cannot dicover: o that according
to this Diviion, different Remedies may be given the more uccesfully, as occaion requires.

2. The firt are the Ulcers and Chancres, which are caued by a light and uperficial adheion of ome matter, that hath not penetrated more inwardly. I add this ditinction, becaue I do not now intend to peak of thoe that are made in the Ureter, by the paage of Virulent matter in Claps or Gonorrheas; nor of uch as are the Symptomes of the univeral Pox, ince the manner of treating them is much different, and that they do depend on other degrees.

This particular Pox is nothing ele in the beginning, but the ruption or dilaceration of the uperficial Fibres of the skin, or pellicules that cover the parts to which the matter doth adhere; o that no other Name mut conequently be given to it, than that of Venereal Ulcers: epecially if we will not do like Ignorants or Impotors, who make the mallet Excoriations pas for Chancres of a mot difficult cure, and they do not indeed cure them, but with a great deal of pains and time, becaue they dres them with cautick burning Medicines, which
make them become very painful, hard, and apt to uppurate, though oftentimes the gentlet deiccatives are ufficient to cure them in three or four days.

Thee Ulcers may indeed happen in all parts of the body, becaue they are all capable of an impure Contact, but the more tender and delicate ones are mot ubject to them, by reaon that the impure Salts do more eaily tick in their uceptible ubtance; whence it comes to pas, that the Yards in Men, the Privities in Women, the Teats in Nures, and the Mouth in Infants, are the parts which are mot commonly infected with them.

3. That which ought to be done towards their Cure while they are in this condition, conits principally in drying them up like other Ulcers, only regard mut be had to the matter that caues them, and proper Deiccatives employed for breaking the points of the Salts they contain, and to oppoe their penetration, which is o much the rather to be feared, as it is done inenibly.

The following Liquours will very well anwer this firt repect, if you wah the Ulcers twice a day with them, and lay
Tents upon them, that are dipt in thee Liquours, oberving always to give uch a trength to them as is mot agreable & proper to the particular Temperaments of the bodies and parts, on which you hall apply them, and this by encreaing the quantity of Pouders to render them the tronger, or ele that of the Waters to make them the weaker.
Take of the eventh Water of unlakt Lime one pound, Spirit of Vitriol, Salt of Saturn, and Verdegreae, of each half a drachme.
Or ele, Roe and Plantain Water, of each half a pound, Aqua-vitae two ounces, Orpiment a drachme and a half, Verdegreae two cruples, Aloes half a drachm.

Or again, white Wine a pound, Roe and Plantain Water, of each four ounces, Orpin two drachmes, Verdegreae one drachm, Mirrh and Aloes of each a cruple; Make the Liquours according to Art, for the ue above mentioned.

To anwer the econd repect that I remarked, you mut ue both Purgatives and Diureticks, if the Ulcers are upon the Yard of a Man, the Genitals of a Woman, or about the Groin of either of
them; or ele you may ue inwardly Sudoriicks, that drive from the Center to the Circumference, if they are in any other parts.

4.
