It mut be epecially oberved, that the Purgatives, which you hall make ue of for this effect, be trong enough to move Nature, and help it to drive by Stool any impure matter that might have penetrated a little more inwardly, than the Ulcers which appear to you; and alo that they be not violent enough to attract the Humours from the remoter parts; for this attraction would help the matter to make a further penetration, then it would otherwie have been able to do of it elf, and o caue by this means the univeral Pox, which you do endeavour to avoid: And here you may take notice that the greatet part of Men are themelves the caues of the frauds and deceits that are done to them; for there are very many who will never think themelves well purged, unles they have felt exceive pains, and cruel gripes in their guts, and unles they go to Stool fiveteen or twenty times at leat: though to peak the truth, Nature can never endure thee extraordinary and violent
Motions without the diminution or depravation of their Functions, which nevertheles are the principal Agents in the eparation and expulion of Impurities.

If you deire therefore to avoid thee excees, you'll find nothing more afe than an Infuion of Senna with Salt of Tartar, in which you may alo diolve the Syrups of Roes or Peachflowers; proportionating the does to the age and trength of the Patient you take in hand.

5. The Diuretiks you mut make ue of to repel by Urine, are Crytal Mineral, which you may give from half a drachm to two or three, and the Spirits of Vitriol and Sulphur, from ix to thirty drops in Pellitory Water, or an Aperitive Ptianne, you may prepare with the Roots of Strawberries, wild Succhory, Gras and Dandelion.

Thoe of Parly, Fennil, Sperage, and Ret-harrow, are much more aperitive than the former, and divers forms of Ptiannes may be prepared with them, that are ueful indeed to ome, but may have very ill effect on perons extremely hot and dry, as well as Radih-eed bruied, and taken in white Wine, which is notwithtanding a mot powerful Aperitive.

For the Sudoriicks that are taken inwardly, you may ucceively make ue of the Spirit of Harts-horn, which you may give in half a Glas of Carduus-water, from ix to twenty drops, or a like number of grains of its volatile Salt diolved in the ame Water.

But among all you'll find none to have a greater effect than the Pouder, or volatile Salt of Vipers, if you give the firt from ten to thirty grains, and the latter from five to fiveteen, in equal parts of Cinnamon and Carduus-waters, or in the Water that remains in the ditillation of this ame Salt.

6. It remains to ay, that thee Evils do not long continue under the Name of Ulcers imply; for it is well known that the matter which caues them doth ometimes ininuate more deeply, and by this means doth make another degree of the Pox; but it more often happens, that by long continuance in the exulcerated part, it makes the Ulcers turn into Chancres, after the manner I poke of before. Wherefore it is good to oberve, that you dres them in this condition with Ecaroticks and Suppuratives, becaue you mut conume the hardnes that is
found in them, for fear of leaving a ferment in the parts, that might produce afterwards a far greater Evil, than you are going to detroy.

They who follow the ordinary Practice in this cae, are content to apply Red Precipitate, which in truth makes a skar when it is good, but that a light and uperficial one, uch as is not able to hinder the hardnes from encreaing in latitude and profundity, and from remaining alo after their Cicatrice, what time oever is employed towards their conumption.

Some do make ue of ublimate Corroive, but beides that it caues intolerable pains during the Operation, it attracts watry fluxions on the parts it is applyed to, which are very hard to diolve, and do beides dipoe the parts to a Gangrene, and this principally in thoe parts that are near the paages which erve for expulion of the Excrements.

The caues of thee misfortunes, and many others, is an Errour of ome ancient Authors, that every body may eaily be convinced of, yet hath nevertheles been received by way of Tradition, by the greatet part of thoe who have written
ever ince, or do till write on this ubject; according to which Errour they repreent Quickilver to be like a Ferret that goes and earches out the Venereal matter in all parts of the body, for to expel it thence preently, as this little Animal doth the Connies out of their Holes: For which Opinion nevertheles they have had no other proof than an indeterminate prejudice, that hath for its foundation nothing but pretended occult and pecifick qualities, which no body can undertand. Nevertheles we know they look on no other Remedies to be otherwie than to be impotent of unueful for thee orts of Maladies. And o we mut not at all wonder, that they are o tiff and refractory, in never making ue of any other Cauticks than uch as are made with Mercury, which in good truth is the mot aured Remedy for raiing the Criis of the univeral Pox: but this only by reaon of uch Motions and Actions, as may be determinate and known. Whatoever is the truth of it, you'll find by Experience, that the Cautick Stones, which are prepared of unlackt Lime, and the Cineres Clavellati, have a much more certain effect, ince they caue a
skar more profound than Red Precipitate, and act with les pain than Sublimate Corroive.

You mut ue them notwithtanding with prudence and dicretion, and remember that a part already exulcerated is more eay to penetrate, than when it is covered with its skin; and conequently you mut ue them in a maller quantity, and they mut be limited to fit places only, by means of a Plater with a hole in the middle of it, of the exact bignes you deire to make your skar, and this to hinder the Salts from overpreading themelves, after they have been diolved by the moiture of the Ulcer.
But if you will be till more aured in what you do, you may then make ue of the Lapis Infernalis, with which you may ee and conduct the Operation as it were in an intant.

After having made a skar by ome of thee means, but more particularly by the two lat, you may procure the fall of it with the common Suppurative, in which you may afterwards mix a little Red Precipitate, and burnt Alum, to encreae the Suppuration, and conume the hardnes that may remain. But if it is coniderable
or you have to do with a body Dry and Melancholick; you may add with good tore of the foreaid Ointment, a little Sublimate Corroive, and wah the Ulcer every time you dres it with the lat Collyre of Liquour I decribed, adding a little Aegyptiack when there is need, to make it more deterive.

You may alo lay over the Tents the Plater of Mucilages, in which you hall have mixed 4 or 6 ounces of Mercury for every pound, and rub the places about the part with the Neapolitan Ointment double or treble of Mercury, in the mean time not forgetting the Purgatives that you mut reiterate on this occaion, as well as the other general Remedies I have propoed for a preervation from the univeral Pox.

7. When thee orts of Michiefs are on the Yard of a Man, there happens ometimes a Phymois to the prepuce, either by the Patient's negligence, or the ignorance of him that takes the cure in hand, and this hinders him from being able to uncover, or dres the Ulcers or Chancres that are underneath. The common way of remedying this Accident, is to make one or two Inciions, and this Operation
is o much the more ubject to unhappy conequences, as the part is already afflicted, and therefore more dipoed for receiving Fluxions; and therefore you will do much better to try ome Emollient Fomentations, and Cataplams, that you may prepare with the Decoction and Reidence of Mallow-leaves, Roots of Marh-Mallows, and Lin-eed, not forgetting the frictions of the Ointments, and application of the Platers I named before. During which, you mut mundifie the Ulcers, and Chancres, as well as you can, with the Collyres or Liquours before decribed; of which Liquours you may often make Injections under the Prepuce, with a little Syringe, oberving to tretch it by little and little with your fingers, by drawing it toward the root of the Yard, as often as you dres your Patient, till the Gland becomes again wholly uncovered; but all this mut be done very gently, and without any violence, for otherwie there will happen a Paraphymois, which is an Accident much wore than the former; for beides that the Balanus is uffocated, and cannot by any means be uncovered, this uffocation caues uch a pain, as preently draws
Fluxion, Inflammation, and Gangrene, if all poible care be not uddenly ued.
Some have indeed very happily cured this Indipoition, by only bathing the Yard or Belly in cold Water, but this principally in its beginning.

All the Remedies decribed againt the Phymois are alo ueful in the Paraphymois, when there is time to make ue of them. But oftentimes one is obliged to practie and prefer the Inciions before any of the other.

Now I hall not ay any thing of the means how to cicatrize the Ulcers and Chancres, ince they do principally conit in mundifying them well, and Nature labours enough of her own accord to reunite the divided parts, when the Phyician knows how to remove the Impediments.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the other particular Poxes, that are called Claps and Virulent Gonorrheas.

argument.p: 1. That the Salts which caue thee orts of Poxes are very Volatile, and have ome imilitude and ome difference between them. 2. Divere neceary Obervations on the Method of Curing them. 3. Concerning the Inflation or Swelling, and Inflammation of the Testicules, with the means of Healing them. 4. Of Carnoities that ometimes follow thee firt Michiefs, and of their Remedies. 5. A very ueful Obervation on particular Poxes.

div.p:
1. THe other particular Poxes, which I have aid do happen to the parts our enes cannot dicover, are Claps, and Virulent Gonorrheas; which are the effects of a very ubtile, or rather volatile matter, ince in Women it often paes from the Vagina (wherein the Seed is received) into the Ejaculatory Veels, and into their Teticules; and ince it paes in Men all along the Ureters,
to make their adheion to the ame Veels, and to the Bladder, without leaving nevertheles in the one or in the other any marks at all of its paage, in the parts it goes through.

Though Virulent Claps, or Heats of Urine, do never happen without Gonorrheas, that is to ay, without the corruption and flowing of the Seed, yet they mut not be confounded indifferently together under thee two Names, as ome Authors have very inconiderately done; becaue this lat Indipoition remains ometimes a great while after the former, and it is een ometimes to happen alone, that is to ay, without Exulceration, and apparent Inflammation, though indeed it be actually caued by the preence of impure Salts which poes the Spermatick Veels. Nevertheles as the Gonorrhea is ineparable from a Clap, and the Remedies which agree to it as an Accident, do alo erve for curing it, when it is a Dieae apart, it will not be neceary to treat of it here more particularly; it may uffice to acquaint you, that it is often taken in Women for the Whites, for want of oberving, that its Flux is continual, whereas that of the
Whites is almot always Periodical and Mentrual.

Furthermore I have ufficiently explicated otherwie what I mean by Virulent Claps, and after what manner I conceive them to be produced, that there is no need of making repetitions here; I believe alo that all the diviions which I could make of it be altogether ueles, becaue I do not intend to peak but only of thoe that are caued by the entrance and adheion of ome Venereal Salt, or ele becaue its Accidents do ufficiently ditinguih it from uch as happen by violent Exercies, by the ue of fermented Liquours, and by other caues. Therefore I believe it will uffice to give you in this Chapter the circumtances it is neceary to oberve for the curing uccesfully all the Accidents that accompany this I am now going to peak of, or ele for auredly preventing the univeral Pox, that might otherwie follow.

2. Inflammation may be aid to be the mot preing Accident of all that happen in this degree of the Pox, for 'tis by it that the matter which runs out is rendered the more harp and corroive, that the Ulcers of the paages become greater and
more profound, that the pains grow inupportable, and latly that the means of making Urine become o extream difficult, nay and ometimes in a manner impoible: 'Tis therefore requiite to take care betimes of preventing, or ele curing it by cooling Remedies, uch as may be thoe I am now going to propoe.

Some perons, whom we mut by no means imitate, do begin with Bloodletting in the Arm, which may be apt to attract or drive the Venereal matter more inwardly into the body, and mut conequently be upected as dangerous; others are not afraid to let Blood in the Foot, which alo may have the ame effect, or ele precipitate the Defluxion into the Stones; wherefore you hould abtain from them both, and prefer the ue of the following Ptianne, which will erve at the ame time to cool the parts, drive the matter outwards, and diminih its Acrimony.

Take the Roots of white Lillies, and Marh-Mallows, of each a pound, Sorrel half a hand full, Liquorih a ufficient quantity, Barley three hands full, Lineed two ounces, common Water four and twenty pounds; make a Ptianne
the uual way, remembring to pres the remainder well, for to draw out the Mucilage the better.

Add in every Bottle of this Ptianne ten or twelve drops of the Spirit of Vitriol, and make, your Patient drink of it as much as his tomach will bear, and this indifferently at any hour, day, or night.

Though this Ptianne be often ufficient to anwer the intentions I have named, when you begin in good time to make ue of it; yet it is found every day in ome perons, that the malignity of the matter, and dipoition of the body and parts, do caue the Inflammation to grow o great, as to communicate it elf to the Reins, and neck of the Bladder, o that the Patients do uffer extreme pains, when they are in Bed, during the erection, and in urining: but this more particularly in Men; for the Convulion of the Nerves of their Yard, which by retiring toward their origine do well, and thereby render this part crooked, or bended, doth caue the degree of the Pox in which it is aid to be corded and tringed; and in which alo you mut add to the fore-named Ingredients
for the Ptianne, two ounces of the Cold Seeds, half an ounce of white Poppy Seed, and the Juyce of two or three Limons, for to render it more Anodyne, more refrehing, and agreable.
You hall alo give from time to time emulions made of Whey, weet Almonds, and the Seeds and Juyce I have now named.

You may for the ame intention rub the Reins, and Perineum with the Cerecloth of Galen, which you mut afterwards cover with Linnen dipt in Oxyerat that is made of one part of Vinegar, and ix of Roe-water.

The ue of cooling Clyters mut be frequent too, as well as Injections of this quality, which mut be made into the Yard, by means of a little Syringe, and this with luke-warm Milk, for Example, which is marvellous for this effect, and one may make ue of it much more uccesfully than of common Water, to dip the Yard in whil't he urines, and o facilitate the paage of the Urine.

Some of thoe who do not eteem things that are common, chue rather to make ue of the Waters of Night-hade, Roes, and Plantain, to make Injections,
which are indeed Refrigerant and Anodyne, becaue they hinder the matter from flowing, and drive it back by their atriction; but it is a dangerous thing to do o, and therefore you mut have a care of uing them, unles the matter be grown thick, and hath run ufficiently.

Turpentine of Chios, or in defect of it that of Venice, hath a marvellous effect for awaging and qualifying the matter, and driving it out, becaue it very eaily lides into thoe parts, and is very Diuretick. You may give it in Bolus or Pills from two drachms to half an ounce, or its Spirit drawn Chymically from five drops to fifteen, in Aperitive Waters or Ptiannes.

Experience will let you know that the Salt, which is called Polychret, is a powerful Remedy to drive out the Venereal Salts, if you diolve two drachms of it in two glaes of the former Ptianne, or of Pellitory-water, to give it a little after the Inflammation is pat, and reiterate it after this manner two or three times, augmenting the Doe each time with a drachm more.

After the ue of thee Remedies, you mut begin to purge gently, with a light
Infuion of Senna, Crytal Mineral, and Caia, and may reiterate this Purge ome days afterwards, augmenting the Doe, or ele adding other Medicaments that are mot convenient to the preent Dipoitions.

When the matter hall come to run more white, more thick, & in les quantity, you may then hinder its effluxion for altogether, hutting up and cloing the Spermatick Veels by atringent and inward Remedies, whil't you are cleaning and deiccating the Ulcers of the Ureter, with deterive and deiccative Injections.

Some of thoe that abue Phyick and its Remedies, do trive to top the matter that runs in Claps, only with atringent Injections; which caues the matter to ink into the more inward parts, and o conequently there happens a greater Evil then they pretended to cure, or at leat the effluxion begins again o oon as they have left off the ue of thee pretended Remedies: in o much that they are compelled ometimes fifteen or twenty times to reaume the ue of them, without attaining the end they propoed themelves. For thee Injections cannot
go in Men further than the inward extremity of the common paage to the Seed and Urine, nor in Women further than the neck of the Womb, or the neck of the Bladder; but this happens chiefly, becaue by this means they hinder the evacuation of uch Impurities as may till remain ometimes after the Operation of the former Medicaments, and are too often the only caue of the duration of this Dieae. Now none of this happens, when Stiptick Remedies that are taken inwardly, are ued with prudence; for they cloe the Spermatick Veels by little and little, which by this retriction or compreion do dicharge themelves of their remaining Impurities; o that you may always make ue of them with good ucces, oberving only that you give them at firt in a very mall quantity and this a little after the Purgatives poken of before. To this we mut add nevertheles, that it is ometimes needful not to make ue of them at all, and that Circumtances do ometimes happen wherein they are unprofitable, or dangerous. For it is remarkable in the greatet part of thoe that are thus affected, that the matter which runs out toward
end of their Cure, is nothing ele but the Virus of ome of the Ulcers in the paages, & o conequently its effluxion mut not be hindred by any other Remedies than uch as are cleaning and deiccative. Sometimes alo the extraordinary heat of the Bowels doth nourih and continue the Inflammation and Dilatation of the ejaculatory Veels; o that the alteration and los of Seed cannot be hindered but by a proper Dyet, and cooling Remedies. At other times again the Gonorrhea is caued by Virulent eroities, that fall into the Teticules, and cannot be conumed but by the ue of the Decoctions of China-root, Salaparilla, and the other Sudorificks. Latly it may be perpetual and incurable in Men, when the Caruncula Mammillaris (which huts the Holes through which the Seed paes into the common paage from the Glandulae Protatae) hath been unhappily conumed by ome Ulcer, or ele by corroive Medicaments.

But you mut oberve that the greatet of thee Exceptions do not commonly come to pas, and you mut conider the Atringents, of which I have poken, as the mot aured Remedies in the Cure
of Gonorrheas; & beides it is by the ue and effects of them, that you may bet judge of the neceity of thee others; wherefore you may always try them without danger, and make ue of to this purpoe, for Example, a great Glas of Water, wherein you hall have boiled, half a quarter of an hour, half an ounce of Myrobalans beaten together.
Or ele, of the Tincture of red Roes, drawn in common Water, or the Juyce of Berberries, with the Spirit of Vitriol, and given Morning and Evening from two to ix ounces.

Or again, four parts of Electrum, or intead of it Amber, with one part of Camphire poudered, and incorporated into the Conerve of Roes, the weight of both, to give of it every Morning from half a drachm to a drachm and a half.
But among all the Remedies that may be ued to this intention, you'll find none more aured in their Operation than the following Pills:

Take of Matick in Tears, red Coral, and choen Amber, of each two drachms, Camphir one drachm, Laudanum eight grains; make Pills according to Art, with a ufficient quantity of Syrop of Quinces
to make a Mas, of which you may give from a cruple to a drachm, for each Doe.

As for the Ulcers which may happen in the paages, you may mundifie them with deterive Injections, made with the decoction of French Barley, and Agrimony, in which you hall mix the Syrop of Wormwood, or Honey of Red Roes, with ome drops of the Spirit of Vitriol.
After the deterion you may dry them with the eventh Water of unlackt Lime, in which you hall diolve a little Salt of Saturn.
Or ele, take white Vitriol, Iris of Florence, and Camphire, of each half a drachm, Roch-Alum one drachm, Roe and Plantain-water, of each eight ounces, make Collyres for the foreaid intention.
The Troches of Abbot Rhafis, mixt in the ame Waters, in the Water of ditilled Alum, or its diolution in common Water may alo erve to the ame effect.

3. When the Patients way of living is very irregular, and licentious, or ele when the matter hath been driven back too oon by atringent Injections; latly, when it hath been precipitated by Purges,
that are too violent, or inconideratly given, it preads into the proper Membranes of one of the Teticules, or of both together, where it caues a great and painful Tumour, which ometimes creates more trouble to cure than all the other Accidents.

The ituation of the parts where the Evil lyes, doth indicate to you the neceity of repoe; the defluxion of Humours, Inflammation, and great pain that draws them thither, do alo indicate to you the neceity of revulive Phlebotomys, and Anodyne and cooling Clyters, which you mut reiterate as often as hall be found neceary, to top or divert the Motion of the matter.
Cataplams made of Cows-milk, Crums of White-bread, Yelks of new-laid Egs, and Oyl of weet Almonds, are here very profitable at the beginning.
Fomentations and Cataplams made with Mallow-leaves, Marh-mallow roots, Flowers of Camomille and Melilote, Line-eed and Fleawort-eed, may much contribute to the Cure of this Indipoition.

When the Inflammation and pain hall be taken away by all thee Remedies,
and the Tumour a little mollified, you may begin to ue reolvent Cataplams, uch as are made with the four orts of Farine or Meale boiled in Oxymel, adding to them a little Oyntment of Roes, and Saffran.
Cummin-eed well bruied, and boil'd alo in Oximel to the conitence of a Cataplam.
Latly, the Balom of Sulphur applyed alone, or mixed with Myrrh, in the conitence of a Cere-cloth, as it is decribed by Rulandus.

4. If the Ulcers of the paages have not been cleaned and dryed, as they hould be, the remaining matter thickens, and fixes the Humour, which flows into the ulcerated part; in o much that the Fleh there grows hard, ries by little and little, and at lat hinders the entrance of the Yard, when it happens in the neck of the Womb of a Woman, but doth more often hinder the paage of the Urine in both Sexes, if it be not conumed before it poees the Circumference of the Ureter.

It is more particularly requiite in Men to take care of preventing this extremity, and endeavouring to conume thee excrecencies,
o oon as ever it is perceived, that the Urine doth not make o large a tream as uually, or that it runs out forked and divided. For when it comes to go out but only drop by drop, or is altogether thus uppreed, we are almot always obliged to open the Perineum by an Inciion, or at leat to introduce a Catheter into the Bladder, which in paing along doth caue very grievous pains.

You may eaily conume a Carnoity in its beginning, by excoriating it with a Catheter, and applying thereupon (by the means of a little Candle made of Wax and Turpentine) red Precipitate, calcined Alum, Verdegreae, the pouder of Sabine, and yellow Orpiment; of which Drogues you may prepare everal orts of Remedies. But when it is become very great and hard, you mut firt of all try to render it tractable, by the application of emollient Remedies, uch as are the Fomentations that I have decribed for the welling of the Teticles, or ele the reidence of the Decoction, with which you may make Cataplams for the ame effect, beating it and boiling it to the conitence of Pap.

You may alo make Liniments with
the Oyl of Lillies, Man's Fat, or the Neapolitan Oyntment, and apply thereupon the Plater de Vigo, or rather that of Mucilage with Mercury.
Some have found a great deal of help from a Fumigation that is raied from Aqua-vitae, or Vinegar, cat upon hot tones or bricks.

When the Carnoity hall have been a little mollified by thee, or other means, you may make ue of the Corroives decribed before, or put twelve grams of Sublimate Corroive in an ounce of the Plater of Mucilage, which will auredly prove of great effect, if you ue it dexterouly; that is to ay, if you apply it in a mall quantity, and this directly upon the excrecence.

Moreover, I hall not peak particularly of thoe that happen to Women in the ame paages, by reaon that you may alo conume them with the Remedies I have already decribed; and this alo with much more eae than thoe, which happen in the common paage or the Ureter of Men.

5. You mut oberve that the particular Poxes of which I have poken are found to be ometimes accompanied with
the univeral Pox, becaue it ometimes happens to appear jut at the ame time; or the Venereal Salts are now and then o volatile and penetrant, that they force againt the oppoition of Nature and its Preervatives. In this cae it is to no purpoe to make ue of the greatet part of the particular Remedies I have propoed; ince by taking away the univeral Infection of the body by the general Remedies that will be decribed in the equel of this Book, you'll detroy the Caue of the Dieae, whereoever it may ly, and the Accidents will eaily vanih almot all of themelves by this means.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the Natural Cries of the Univeral Pox.

argument.p: 1. General diviion of the Cries of the Pox, and why the Evacuations that follow the Application of its Remedies, may be o called. 2. Of the Natural Cries of the Pox, and first of thoe that terminate it with other Dieaes. 3. Of thoe that are produced imply by the Oppoition of Nature. 4. Of Buboes and Poulains in particular.

div.p: SEeing the univeral Pox doth conit in a general Infection of the body, it cannot be-terminated but by uch Cries, as are able to carry away all its Impurities.
Thee Cries may be raied either by Motions purely Natural, or ele by the proper Actions of Mercury, and the other Remedies.

I know well enough that thoe who tick cloely to what the Ancients have taught, will not allow of this diviion, becaue according to them the Cries of
Dieaes are only the productions of Nature, and not the effects of Remedies; Whereupon it is neceary to remark, that the Evacuations which follow the application of Remedies againt the Pox, and particularly that of Mercury, mut not be conidered imply like thoe that are een to follow, when the Veels are opened, or after the ue of Vomits and Purges; becaue thee lat have always determinate Motions, whereas thoe others I peak of are made either by the mouth, or by the pores, or iege, or by urine, according as Nature finds the Impurities or paages bet dipoed; whence we may eaily conclude that they are properly the works of Nature, and that the Remedies which are employed for this effect, do principally erve to move and dipoe the bodies to their purification by an agitation of all the Humours.

2. But to return to thoe which are caued by Motions purely Natural, they may may be ditinguihed into uch as are provoked by the Caues of ome other Dieaes, which do render the Pox ometimes complicated, or into uch as are made imply by the oppoition of Nature.

The Dieaes which may caue the former, are, for Example, the Plague, Pleureie, and generally Feavours, but principally thoe that are called Malignant, whoe Cries may be able to carry off the Pox, becaue they never happen but after their Caues have procured a great ebullition in the blood, by which Nature is ometimes o violently moved, that he makes an extraordinary effort to eparate all the Impurities that are mixed with it. But eeing the Pox may be carried off after this manner as different ways as there are different Natural terminations of it, and becaue this matter cannot be treated of here without confuion, I hall not peak more amply of it, but do believe it will be ufficient to explicate in this Chapter the other orts of Cries, which may be aid to be peculiar to the Pox.

3. Seeing the Venereal matter is venomous, ubtile, and penetrant, it rarely makes its Attache any coniderable time on the uperficial parts, without entring into the Veels, and mixing with the blood; and as there is nothing more ordinary than thoe orts of adheion, there would conequently be nothing
more familiar than the univeral Pox, if Nature did not oppoe its introduction, and make ue of all its force to hinder a mixture and ininuation that is o contrary to it. Nay we ee, that he prevents as much as poible the diorder that this poion may be apt to make. For when he is not able to ecape its Introduction, he knows how to act againt it another manner of way, by eparating it from the Humours that are pure, and driving it away with the ordinary Excrements through commodious paages.

Thee paages may be the ame as erve alo for Natural Purgations, uch as the Terms of Women, and the regulated Hemorrhoides of certain Men, or for extraordinary Evacuations, as ordid Ulcers, or latly for the univeral purification of the blood, and the Emunctories. But as the Venereal matter is driven almot inenibly through the former ways that I have mentioned, & eeing Nature hath no need of aitance in this Operation, I hall not give any more precie explications of them, and hall be contented to decribe the means of making the Crie ucceed well, that often happens through the latter.

4. Whereas the Genital parts do erve oftner than any other for the introduction of Venereal Salts, the Groin which is very near them doth uffer the impure Tumours by which they are driven out, more commonly than the other Emunctories; after the ame manner as the Humours that erve for a Criis to the Petilence, do rather happen to well under the Arm-pits, becaue they are nearer the Breat, which firt received by inpiration the infected Air that caued this Dieae. But though it be eay to remark that thoe ort of Tumours are always made by ome Critical Motion, it is known nevertheles that the efforts, which Nature makes on this account would often prove to no purpoe, if he were not econded by the application & action of Remedies that Phyick does furnih us with. An Example of this truth is oberved particularly in Buboes or Poulains, that often appear in the Groins, when the impure matter hath been driven thither, but yet diappear again ometimes, when it hath not been topt there by Attractives; which happens not in the Cries that are made the other was I have poken of, by reaon
that they have nothing to hinder the paage of Impurities, and becaue the Humours that run through them do at the ame time erve to extend and diolve the Venereal Salts, which are eaily driven out by this means. But it is not the ame when a Bubo begins to rie, the little Humour that there is mixed with thoe Salts, thickens by this mixture, becaue it remains a long time under the skin, and can have no iue at all but by piercing it; o that thee Cries can eldom become perfect, unles Nature is aited with Art.
The intention which you ought to have for to anwer this repect, doth principally conit in augmenting the Emotion of Nature, and procuring a Suppuration.

This Augmentation may be made two manner of ways. The firt is, by driving it from within outwardly, by the ue of hot Aliments, for Example, of Wine, or ele of Remedies of the ame quality, uch as Treacle, or Treacle-water. The econd is by attracting and digeting the Tumour by Topicks.

The attraction and digetion of Buboes is wont to be made ordinarily, with the
Plater Diachylum, that is compounded of Galbanum, Opoponax, and the other hot and attractive Gums. But I know by experience, that it attracts but weakly, when the Gums enter into it in a mall Doe, and that it becomes on the contrary Reolvent, when too great a quantity of them enters; o that its application doth not hinder the Tumours from diappearing ometimes, and this chiefly in Melancholick and Phlegmatick perons, whoe Natural heat is but weak; wherefore you mut prefer at leat for uch perons the following Cataplam, which hath for certain a much better effect.

Take eight or ten Snails with their hells, ix Lilly-roots, two ounces of freh Butter, and three ounces of old Rye-leaven, make Cataplams of it, and apply them hot, and renew them every ix hours; remembring to augment the Doe of the Leaven, when you would attract more trongly in robut Bodies, and alo to diminih it for thoe that have their skin tender and delicate, to avoid thoe excoriations which might otherwie be feared. Moreover, this Remedy hath not only the vertue of attracting, but alo that of topping and fixing the Humour
in the part, by contributing much to the Suppuration.

When the Tumour is rebellious, and advances not o much as may be wihed, a great Cupping-glas may be uccesfully applyed upon it every twelve hours, which mut be left each time, till it hath made a coniderable attraction; after which you may take it off, and put upon the point of the Tumour a Tent of the bignes of a farthing, on which you may put an Ointment made of equal parts of Bailicum, and Leaven fermented with the Spirit of Vitriol, to apply afterwards upon it the Plater, or ordinary Cataplam.

After you hall have brought the matter to Suppuration by thee means, you mut open the Bubo in the mot eminent part of it, or a very little lower, according to the Longitude of the Fibres of the Groin, with Potential Cauters, and the Lancet; after which, you may make ue of the ordinary Suppuratives and Mundificatives, by putting at firt upon it the Plater Diachylum, and afterwards that of Mucilage with Mercury; and at lat you may treat it like other impure Tumours, remembring to purge frequently toward
the latter end by Stool, and by Urine.

It is remarkable that there are ome Impotors here, and other where who do make ill ue of thee Remedies, and do make artificial Buboes appear, on thoe that have none really, but ometimes doubt of it, by reaon of ome Glandules filled with eroities, or other edematous Tumours, which happen either during, or after ome particular Poxes.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Plants which have been eteemed capable to carry off the Pox by Sweat.

argument.p: 1. General Obervations on thee Sudorifick Plants, by which is proved that they are not able to Cure the Pox neither in Europe, nor in the Indies. 2. Particular Obervations on Guaiacum. 3. On Saafras. 4. On China. 5. On Saraparilla.

div.p:
1. Before we peak of the Cries that are artificially raied to cure the
Univeral Pox, I have thought it convenient to remark ome ueful Obervations on the Sudorifick Plants, which were heretofore accounted infallible for this effect, and ome others upon Quickilver; which are of o much the more importance, as they are at preent alo acknowledged for its mot aured Remedy, without any bodie's endeavouring nevertheles hitherto to undertand why and how they come to have uch power.

Thee Plants, or their parts which are ordinarily in ue, are, for Example, the Wood Guaiacum, and the Roots of Saafras, China, and Saraparilla, which have been brought hither from divers places of both Indies, and at everal times; they have all had their turns of the common advantage new things uually meet with; the Dearet, and Newet have been always mot eteemed, and the greatet part of Authors have ued this occaion to peak Wonders of them and make profit by this means of the prejudice of Men's minds; o that they have been generally acknowledged for the overaign, pecifick, & aured Remedies of this Dieae.

Thee Abues have made way for many others, Empyricks have ditributed
them for things of a mot pretious value, the Chymits have drawn their Extracts and Quinteences out of them, which they have old at the price of their weight in Gold; Mountebanks, and uch as ditribute ecret Remedies, have put a diguie upon them by the mixture of many other Ingredients; latly, ignorant people have preferred the ue of them before all other Remedies.

Becaue the Stories and Relations of thoe that have made Voyages into the Indies, did perwade us that the Indians were perfectly cured by a Decoction of thee Plants, and the Impotors of Europe took care to render their ucces good in all appearance by the deceitful Cure of imaginary Dieaes; All people were a long time entertained in this Errour, and every body continued obtinate in the ue of them, notwithtanding the fale Experiments that were daily made, which were rather imputed to the indicret and careles ue of them, than to their proper fault. Wherefore Men tryed everal ways of preparing and employing them, which nevertheles were acknowledged to be ueles, as well as the common and ordinary Preparations.

This obliged thoe that had epecially trived to keep them in vogue, to acknowledge and declare that the ame advantages could not be drawn from them here, as were pretended to be infallible in their Natural Climats. But let it hould eem ridiculous to condemn abolutely uch things as have been generally approved but a little before, ome of them therefore taught, that the Providence of God had made them grow only for the Cure of thoe Countries, where this Dieae was uppoed to have its origine, but that they could not be tranported o far as us without the los and alteration of their Vertues.

Thee Propoitions do not prove nevertheles that the Indians are better cured than we by the ue of thee Plants; ince I have proved in another place that the Pox hath till been in all places, and at all times; And it may be further added, that if God had permitted the tranportation of this Dieae without alteration of its form, he would alo by the ame Reaon have permitted the tranportation of its Remedies too, without diminution of their Vertues. Beides there would have been no need, but only
of augmenting the Does, to render the Compoitions that were made of them more trong and active. But that which particularly lets us ee, thoe people are not cured but only in appearance too, by the Decoction of thee Simples, is, that they do deiccate the bodies here as much or little les than they do in the Indies; and that this deiccation doth make the Accidents often diappear for the preent, & leave only the appearance of a Cure; in o much that they do always caue a new fermentation afterwards, and appear ome other time more terrible than before.

Whatoever you pleae to think of it, it is certain this Opinion was at lat found and acknowledged to be true, and the greatet part of our Phyicians began at lat to diabue themelves; o that divers Eays were made to dicover ome other Remedy for this Evil. Our Apothecaries prepared for this effect divers orts of Purgative and Vomitive Potions, Antidotes, and Cordial Confections, Platers, Ointments, and generally all kinds of Compoitions of the Galenical Pharmacie. The Chymits did not fail on their part to try their Elixirs, their Arcanums
Magiteries, Quinteences and Extracts, both Emetick, Cathartick and Diaphoretick. Latly, after a great many proofs of the like nature, it was happily found out, that thoe who had the Pox could be cured indeed by Frictions with Mercurial Ointments, which erved heretofore for the pretended Leproie, of which I have poken before. Nevertheles eeing thee Sudorifick Decoctions did heretofore take away the appearance of it in ome perons, they were not neglected altogether; and the eteem that had been made of them formerly did till contribute much to the ue that hath been made of them ince, and is continued now a days, which is to give them for preparing the Bodies, on which Mercury is deigned to be applied.

Moreover it is not hard to undertand how the Accidents of the Pox can diappear for ome time, without detroying its Caue, ince it is evident enough, by what I have already aid in the Firt Section of this Book, that it eentially conits in a venomous Salt mixt with the Blood, which ferments and ets it a boiling; o that during this Ebullition there
continually aries out of the Veels that contain it many vaporous or erous matters, which produce different Symptomes, according to their Quality, or Quantity, or Parts where they adhere. Now eeing thee ame Matters can be eaily conumed by Sudorificks, Diureticks, and generally by deiccative Remedies; we mut not at all wonder, if their Effects do not appear for a time after the ue of a Decoction of thee Plants, and if nevertheles the Ferment that raied up thoe Vapours, do till continue mixed with the Blood, ince it is a Salt diolved, fermented and confounded with it, that cannot be ufficiently carried off by matters that pas away o quickly.

I know very well it may be aid, that one can hardly believe how the Indians hould be cured only in how, and hould be o long deceived without perceiving their errour. But oberve how I conceive that may be done: Strumpets are there wonderful common, and they make ue of them with the Brutality that is uual to uch as have little Religion in them; which makes this dieae o familiar among them, that they have reaon to think they
contract it till anew again. For indeed it is not at all likely, that they hould be oblig'd o frequently to reiterate their Cures, as Hitories and Relations tell us they do, if they really had any aured Remedies to detroy this Dieae in its Root.

I do not mean (as I have already aid) that the Univeral Pox can never be cured by thee Sudorificks, or by other Remedies more ordinary and common, whilt it is yet but in its firt degree, that is to ay, when its Matter hath not been perfectly united with the Blood by a Fermentation: But beides that this Degree doth continue but a little while, it is not always liable to be rightly ditinguihed, and Mercury doth carry it off with o much promptitude and facility, that it were indeed vain to try other Remedies.

Notwithtanding that thee Obervations are founded both upon Reaon and Experience, and do prove by thee two means that thee Plants are not Specifick againt this Dieae; we mut avow nevertheles that there are ome Occurrences, wherein they may much contribute to the Cure, eeing there are ome Bodies that mut be abolutely deiccated before the application
of Mercury; Wherefore it is neceary to take notice of the Obervations that I have made on each in particular, to know more preciely the ue that mut be made of them.

2. The Wood Guaiacum gives a yellowih Tincture, more harp, and more ditateful, but alo more deiccative than that of the other three Simples named before. Some Authors pretend that this Effect proceeds from its Sudorifick vertue; and others contend to prove that it is much more Diuretick: but which oever it is, 'tis always true that it conumes the Phlegm and Seroities, carrying them off either by Sweat or Urine. And that thee different motions do principally proceed from the internal dipoition of thoe that ue them, ince it is found by Experience that it doth make ome weat and others urine. I have often oberved, that it may be rendred more proper to open the Pores, by adding to its Decoction ome French Barley, which doth alo render it weeter and more agreeable.

We have reaon alo to believe, that the manner of uing it among the greatet part of Americans doth not a little
contribute to the rendring of it Sudorifick; for they firt heat themelves by violent and extraordinary Exercies, before they preume to drink of its Decoction, and after they have drunk of it, they lie in Cotton-beds hung up, and o continually winging, which gives a new agitation to the Humours by uch continued motions, and makes them evaporate more eaily by wayes already dipoed.

We mut grant indeed that the Volatil and Eential Salt, which caues it to produce this Effect, doth more abound in that which they employ, than this that is brought over to us; becaue they cut it freh from young Trees, and the Sprigs of old ones, in which the Univeral Spirit, that caues the Vegetation of Plants, is doubtles more active, and les divided; and it is for this reaon requiite to make choice of the mallet and yellowet, becaue the greatet & blacket is mot likely to be taken from old aples Trunks.

Such as make the goodnes of Remedies to conit in the trength of their activity do rather employ the Bark of this ame Wood, which is in good truth more drying than all the ret of the Tree, but is accompanied with o much Heat and Acrimony, that I would not counel
any body to make ue of it; and it would be much better on an occaion to render the ue of the ordinary Decoction longer and more frequent.

3. The part of Saafras which is commonly made choice of, and which I eteem alo to be the bet, is its Root, of which nevertheles there is little ue made at preent; either becaue its Vertue is not well known, or becaue the other Sudorifick Roots are dearer, and o conequently more eteemed. It is true notwithtanding, that its Decoction hath a very pleaant and agreeable Smell and Tate, and that ue may be made of it as well as of Guaiacum, to conume the uperfluous Humidities, in driving them either by Sweat, or Urine, or ele by iege, adding ome light Catharticks to it.

I have oberved nevertheles that its Root doth not deiccate o powerfully as Guaiacum, and that it is conequently good for uch as mut be more moderately dried. But more force may be found in the Bark of its Wood, which alo gives a Tincture yet more Aromatick, more quick and harp.

4. Whereas the Root of China is the dearet of udorifick Druggs, that erve to prepare or cure uch as are infected
with the Pox, the Merchants and Travellers, who have brought it hither from the places where 'tis found, have all endeavoured to boat its good effects very much to its advantage, that they might thereby have the better Market of it; and its Vertues have been alo o much exaggerated by ome Authors, that uch as have preferred their Report before the Experience and Obervations which they might have made themelves, would have thought they had laboured in vain, if they had preumed to cure the Pox without employing it to this intent. Nevertheles we mut acknowledge, that this preoccupation deerves to be blamed, and that this Root hath nothing in it proportionable to the eteem that hath been made of it, nor to the dearnes with wich it hath been old: eeing the Decoctions that are made of all thee Drugs, do principally and mot properly erve to dry the Bodies of uch as ue them, and the Decoctions of the other two I now mentioned may be employed to this effect with more ucces.

Not that this may not be very ueful, to prepare uch as hould be more gently deiccated. Yet it may be alo let alone,
when occaion erves, only by diminihing the Does of thoe that are tronger, or augmenting the quantity of thoe that are weaker.

5. The Root of Saraparilla is now-a-days more commonly employed to the aboveaid ue, becaue it gives a Tincture very like that of Wine, and its Decoction hath nothing diagreeable for Smell or Tate. Nevertheles I have oberved that it dries omething les than the other three Sudorificks of which I have poken, and that it paes more willingly by way of Urine, than through the Pores: whence it comes to be of great ue for the curing Gonorrheas, that are caued by virulent Seroities, which do ometimes occupy the Teticles and and other parts that erve for the Concoction and Ditribution of the Seed.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Obervations it is neceary to make on Mercury, to know whence the different Effects that follow its application do proceed.

argument.p:
1. Whence it comes to pas that the Qualities of Mercury have not been yet known, and the neceity there is of knowing them. 2. That it eaily joyns it elf with ulphurous and metallick Bodies, and that it is by conequence neceary that it be revived from Cinnaber, to become pure. 3. That it is always in motion, and that it never loes its mobility but only to retake it. 4. That its Sulphurs do render it volatil and penetrant, but its Gravity inclines it to earch downwards. 5 That Reinous ubtances do erve for the diviion of its particles, but Acids do diolve it more perfectly. 6. That Heat ublimes it, but Alkalis does precipitate it. 7. That Acids do diminih its Volatility, but that it is o much the more Corroive as there are Acids
mixed with it. 8. That the diverity of Bodies with which it joyns makes the diverity of its Actions and Effects. 9. That it is no way poyonous in it elf, and that the divers dipoitions of Subjects on which it is applied, do caue the different Effects that do reult from its application.

div.p:
1. SEing the Ancients have not explicated the Qualities of Medicaments, but only by the different degrees of Hot and Dry, Cold and Moit, and thee ame degrees have not been at all known or ditinguihed more preciely than by the Actions and Effects that reult from thee Qualities; we mut not at all wonder, if they have held Opinions o very different on the ubject of Quickilver, ince that this Mineral doth act o diverly, and doth produce uch different Effects, not only in the everal Bodies that receive it, but alo at different times, when received in the ame ubject: Whence it comes to pas that ome have maintained it to be cold, by reaon of the cold Dieaes that it creates; and others have eteemed it to be hot, becaue it doth conume Phlegm,
and deiccates the bodies in which it is made to enter. Some alo have judged it to be Venomous, by reaon of the Accidents that ordinarily arrive to uch as draw it out of the Mines, to Gilders, and other Artificers that make ue of it; and yet ome others again have aerted that it is an Antidote of poions, and an Enemy of Corruption, becaue it generally kills all Vermine, and is ued with ucces in malignant Feavours, the Petilence and Pox; latly all their Conceits on this ubject have been o oppoite, that they have determined nothing at all yet; and modern Authors who have ordained this Remedy againt certain Dieaes, have been contented to ay, that it acts by unknown occult Properties.

Though there is nothing les known or undertood in all Phyick, it is true nevertheles that nothing doth really deerve to be known more, ince the ue of it now a-days is acknowledged to be equally familiar, profitable, and dangerous, and the little knowledge that is generally had of its true Motions, is perhaps the only caue of all the misfortunes that follow its application. This therefore ought to engage you and I (good Reader) to
ue our utmot endeavours to render them more enible, that we may by this means avoid the Reproaches Poterity might otherwie make to our Memory, much more jutly indeed than to that of our Predeceours, ince we now live in a more knowing and inquiitive Age, and the Lights that this Age hath furnihed us with are ufficient for the dicovery of an infinity of excellent Truths, by making rational Applications of what they and our Ancetors have taught us, to what we do now ee, and what curious and new Experiments do continually upply us with. This is that which I do hope to advance your knowledge in, by the equel of my Obervations, wherein I hall endeavour to omit nothing of what may any way erve to render that Manifet, which hath been hitherto uppoed to be Occult. Nevertheles as it is not my deign to play the Naturalit altogether, you mut not expect to find here the compleat Hitory of Mercury. So that if you deire to know the Etymologie of its Names, its divere Definitions, the Mines from whence it comes, the manner of drawing it thence, the means of counterfeiting it, and infinite Circumtances of
the like nature, you may have recoure to many Authors that have amply written of all thee things.

2. The common ways of dividing Mercury in the Galenical Pharmacy, do hew us that it eaily joyns with Sulphurs, eeing that Turpentine, Roen, and fat Bodies that erve for this effect, are of ulphurous and inflammable ubtances. But the truth of this doth principally appear in the compoition of Cinnaber, which every body knows to be a mixture of Sulphur and Mercury together, ublimated Naturally in the bowels of the Earth by the force of the Centrical Heat, or ele Artificially in Furnaces by the violence of Actual Heat; which proves the Chymits do with reaon make its principles conit of a ubtil and ulphurous Earth, eeing it it true that Homogeneous Subtances do always unite more willingly, and the particles of ome mixt bodies do very eaily quit thoe to which they were joyned for to adhere to other bodies that are more Natural and agreable to them; from whence it comes to pas, that Metallick Water which paes through one of its principles and may be aid to be the mot evident,
doth uffer the mixture, union, and amalgamation of this Metal with the greatet part of other Metals: which gives occaion to Impotors to augment its quantity with Lead and Tin; o that it now becomes very difficult to find any of it truly pure, unles one mixes Cinnaber with the havings of Iron to draw out pure Mercury by ditillation. For by this means we are ure to have it in its purity, becaue the other Metals are not volatil enough to mount with it, but remain in the Retort united with the Sulphur and the Iron.

3. Though Mercury unites it elf eaily with other Metals, and a Metallick matter is enibly perceived in its compoition, yet it mut be conidered but as an imperfect Metal, eeing the crudity of its Water, and volatility of its Sulphurs do hinder it from being liable either to diolution by Fire, or to extenion by the Hammer; and that thoe two ubtances are tyed and united together after a manner o proper for Motion, that it always ecapes the power of thoe Agents, and never ubmits it elf to their violence, unles it be fixt by the mixture of other bodies that erve to hold it in diolution.

That which renders the Mercury of uch a mobile, rowling, and fugitive Nature, is its Sphaerical or round Figure, which is Natural to it, and conerves it alo in the eparation of its parts; o that after having diolved it with Acides, and reduced it into a mot ubtile Powder, it may till be perceived to continue in its ancient Form by the means of a Microcope; its Nature being o altogether admirable, that it eems impoible to find means for the abolute detruction of its accidental and exteriour form.

But eeing its roundnes eems lot only by fale appearances, it may be alo aid that it loes its mobility only to retake it again, eeing this lat Accident is but a production of the former; and it is very certain beides that nothing in all the World hath been able to fix it in uch manner, but that it may be revived by the force of Fire, though ome Impotors do maintain the contrary.

4. That which is mot urprizing in this Mineral is, that notwithtanding its Gravity, it ries up with the gentlet heat; that though it is Volatile, yet its own weight erves to precipitate it downwards. The firt of thee contrarieties
may be proved, by putting ome of it upon burning Coals, or ele by oberving the Sublimations that Chymits make of it; the other contrariety may be ufficiently dicovered by putting it upon Tin, Lead, Wood, and epecially upon the Earth, which it doth penetrate o violently, that ome have pretended to be able to dry up a great pond, only by cating into it ome tore of Mercury that might be able to make a hole big enough to give a paage to the Water which hould follow its Motion.

We know eaily enough that Gold & Lead are gros and ulphurous, by their malleability, but the Sulphurs that enter into the Compoition of Mercury eem to dicover themelves chiefly by its volatility, and conjunction with ulphurous ubtances. I have oberved nevertheles that Metals which abound with this principle are more weighty than others, becaue their parts are more perfectly tyed and united together; o that they always have o much the les weight, as they are better digeted, or become more perfect, becaue the parts do continually eparate in digetion, or ele becaue the greatet part of its Sulphurs do exhale,
and o leave empty paces in the mixed. Now eeing Mercury is a Metal very crude and weighty, we may for this reaon ay, that it is alo very ulphurous, as you ee by the things poken before, that its Sulphurs do render it very proper for Motion; and o you ought not to wonder, that it is Volatil, when moved or excited by any Heat, or that without Heat it is proper to penetrate, and ink deep into bodies, ince its weight, fluidiry, and agitation of its Sulphurs, are things ufficient to bear it downwards.

5. Notwithtanding you mut oberve that it doth not always necearily ink downwards, but that it may be rendered purely penetrant and volatil by its diviion; this truth appears in the Compoition and Application of Mercurial Platers and Ointments, in which it is held divided into imperceptible particles by the means of reinous ubtances, that they may the more properly be able to penetrate the pores of all the skin on which they are applyed.

But though this diviion be very ueful, it is nevertheles very imperfect, eeing the gentlet Heat is able to melt the reinous matters that held the Mercury o
divided, and by this means it eaily reunites to appear again in its ancient form; which doth not happen, when it hath been diolved with Acids; for putting the Diolution over the Fire, the Moiture will evaporate, and the Mercury remain at bottom in form of Salt, or ele continuing the Fire, it ublimates to the middle of the Veel; o that after having been thus everal times ublimated, it remains at lat alone, or mixt with very few Acids, without loing nevertheles the form of Salt.

6. I do not mean that Mercury cannot be ublimated by Heat without being divided, but it is very certain that the Heat mut be more or les trong according as the Corpucules of Mercury are gros or heavy; whence it comes to pas that it is divided into very ubtil particles in the Troches that are ued for Fumigations, that it may the eaier be carried of, and with the les violence.

But though it loes its weight when o divided, and its lightnes renders it improper for precipitation, we know notwithtanding by experience that Alkalis will precipitate it, ince by cating Lime-water, or the Oyl or Liquour of Tartar,
on the Diolution of Sublimate Corroive in common Water, the Mercury is een to precipitate in a yellow powder by the firt, and in a green powder by the econd.

7. Furthermore I am not able to undertand why the Red powder of Mercury is now-a-days called Precipitate, eeing it is nothing ele but its Diolution with Aqua fortis, or the Spirit of Nitre, which is afterwards made evaporate to iccity; unles it be becaue the Acids do unite to all parts of it in thee orts of Diolutions, and o by this means render it more fixt, heavy, and if you will too more penetrant than after the ordinary diviions that are made of it with reinous bodies. Whatoever is the Reaon, it is always true that this is no Precipitation at all, and that the Acids thus incorporated with the Mercury, do not hinder it from being ublimated, but only from mounting o high, as it would do if alone, or mixed with reinous Drugs; if o be the Mercury be not in too mall a quantity, or driven by too violent a Heat.

We may eaily conceive, that nothing but the different quantity of Acids doth
render it more or les Corroive, if we make reflection on the manner of dulcifying Sublimate; one part of Sublimate Corroive is mixed with another part of crude Mercury, till the whole Mas appears greyih; afterwards it is ublimated again, and after this econd Sublimation is found to be les Corroive than it was before; becaue ome part of the Acids of its Nitre and Vitriol do fly out of the Sublimatory Veel, and others tick to the neck like mill-dut, but are eaily eparated from the ublimated Mas beides alo that thoe which till remain are more extended by the augmentation of Mercury; o that by thus powdring and ublimating it three or four times, it becomes at lat o ducified, that it may be afely given inwardly in a coniderable Doe, though it were at firt the tronget Corroive and poion.

8. From the fore-going Obervations may be drawn everal Circumtances very ueful for knowing the Motions of Mercury; but chiefly, that it always tends downwards by its own weight, when alone, and in its Natural form; & on the contrary that it penetrates indifferently upwards, downwards, and on
every ide, when it is divided into ubtil particles; that it is heavy and corroive when mixed with Acids; and on the contrary very benign and volatil when eparated and extended by reinous bodies; that Alkalis can precipitate it, when diolved and mixed with Liquours; latly that the diverity of bodies to which it joyns doth erve to ditinguih its Actions and Effects: to which may be added alo ome following Obervations, that erve for a proof of this truth, as well as the Applications that I intend to make of them, when I hall peak of the Cries that it excites. The firt is, that Natural Cinnabre taken inwardly drives the Impurities by Sweat, or inenible Tranpiration, and that there are Sulphurs in our bodies which do mix with it, when taken alone, and do make it produce this effect. The econd is, that there are a great many Acids with which it may joyn too, becaue all Natural Fermentations are made by their means, and the Venereal Salts do change all the Phlegm into this ame quality. The third is, that the effervecences it produces do alo hew that there are ome Alkalis too, which may erve to precipitate it.

9. By what I have now aid, and particularly by the lat three Remarks, you ee that the divers matters which are found to abound in bodies on which Mercury is applyed are the Caues of its different productions, eeing you may be alo atisfied, that it is not poionous in its own Nature, and that all its unhappy effects do principally proceed from the inward dipoitions of mind and body; for when the Spirits are agitated by violent paions, they may then ublimate the Mercury with Impetuoity, even into the very Brain, and caue by this means the mot doleful Accidents that are found to follow its Application. So there may happen Accidents very dangerous too, for not having well corrected the extream Inanition or Repletion of bodies ill dipoed for its Reception. Latly, every body knows, or every body may know, that it is given inwardly without any danger at all againt the Dieae called the Mierere mei, and there's the les fear, when a great quantity of it is given, which will then be the eaier carried off by its own weight, for otherwie it might poibly top in the Intetins, and there become Corroive by its joyning with the Acid Juyces, which there abound.

div.head: SECT. 3. In which the true Method of Artificially raiing the Cries of the univeral Pox is explained.
CHAP. I. Of the Cries that are provoked by common Remedies, and of the Seaons proper for the Application of Mercury.

argument.p: 1. That the general Obervations which were related in the preceding Sections are abolutely neceary for the right undertanding of particular Ones. 2. General Diviion of Artificial Cries, and why common Remedies are tryed ometimes to provoke them. 3. What are thoe Remedies, and why they are not here treated of to the bottom. 4. Of the choice of proper Seaons for the Application of Mercury. 5. Means to correct the oulnes of the Air and Weather.

div.p:
1. WHen Nature is not able of her elf to raie Critical Motions, and one infected with the Pox requires
the peedy Application of your Art, to terminate his Dieae by Artificial Cries: You mut then take into your thoughts thoe general Ideas I have given you, and recal all the Circumtances that may conduce to the particular ue you would make of them, if you deire to compleat happily the Cure of this Dieae. For it is certain that they are of o great importance, as you cannot expect to ucceed well without the Obervation of them, and by judiciouly applying them to the particular Maximes you'll find in the equel of this Book, you'll etablih for your elves and for others an infallible Practice.

2. You mut firt of all oberve that the Cries of the univeral Pox, which are Artificially made by Remedies, may be ditinguihed into uch as are excited by common Evacuatives, or uch as are provoked by Mercury.

Though thee firt Remedies have les aurance in them, yet they are often put in practice, and chiefly when a peron's Health is in a doubtful condition, becaue they are very ueful to ait Nature in preventing this Evil, and are ufficient to Cure it, while it is but in the firt degree;
beides that it is according to the Order of Phyick to begin with things that are mot eay, and if they do not abolutely Cure the Pox, they can erve to take away the preent appearance of it which is a Circumtance very coniderable ometimes in the Junctures wherein, perons may find themelves engaged to retard their Cure.

3. Moreover thee Remedies are uch as open the principal paages of the bodies and expel Impurities through the ways that are mot Natural; for Example the Sudoriick and Diuretick Decoctions of the Simples I have poken of, which do carry off impure Humidities either, through the pores of the body, or by the way of Urine, or ele all the other Drugs that may erve for this effect; Latly all the Purgatives that evacuate groer matters by iege, and in a need Emeticks too which Purge by Vomit. But eeing thee Remedies are o very common, and well known, and that their quality and quantity can never be regulated but by the Judgment and Experience of uch as employ them, I cannot think it neceary to treat particularly of them, becaue all expert and proper perons
have a perfect knowledge of them already, and thoe that are ignorant of them hould never dare to practie, or ue them, without firt demanding Counel of uch as can inform them, and that epecially in things of o great Moment.

4. If you have tryed in vain all the Remedies I now poke of, if the Pox hath pat its firt degrees, latly if your Patient is willing to be cured once for all, without endangering the los of his time, money, and pains, to little or no purpoe, you mut procure the Criis of his Dieae by means of Mercury; and to do it the more uccesfully you mut chooe the mot temperate Months, uch as are March, April, and May, which do make up the Spring of Phyicians, or ele September and October, which make up their Autumn. For the Summer by its exceive Heats doth caue a diipation of the Spirits, and by this means the diminution of the Natural Heat and trength, without which you cannot effect your Cure; and the Winter by its extream Cold doth condenate the pores of the body, cloes up all the Natural paages, concentrates the Natural Heat, Spirits, and Humours, and doth after this manner hinder Nature
from acting as he ought to do in raiing the Criis you deire to procure.

Nevertheles it is not neceary to tick preciely to the Months I named; for though they are commonly the mot proper for this effect, it ometimes happens that they prove very intemperate, as on the contrary there often happens very eaonable mild Weather in the others. Neither is it o very requiite, that all the dayes of the Criis hould be temperate; it may uffice the time of provoking it be mild enough in Winter, that the Humours may the more eaily be et in Motion; and not o extreme hot in Summer, as to keep the Pores too open, and to divert the Salivation by importunate Sweats. For when Nature hath but once well begun a good motion, he pereveres to the end, though the Phyician co-operates but little.

5. Though the Seaonablenes of the Weather, and other Circumtances that I have remarked, be very ueful indeed for the well performing this buines, yet occaions do ometimes happen, wherein they cannot be exactly oberved. The Accidents which the Pox produces, or
the particular affairs of ick perons do ometimes require o udden and preing a Cure, even in very uneaonable times, that there is a neceity of preent treating it, notwithtanding the unhappy occurrences which may then come to pas; and you mut not be too fearful in undertaking uch a Cure at this time. For 'tis certain, that the ill quality of the Air may be corrected, with a great deal of care and neceary application. You may, for example, put your ick in the Shades of the exceive Summer-heats, by chooing a Chamber large enough, whoe Windows are expoed to the North, and cloely hut in the day-time, to hinder the Air and reverberation of the Rayes of the Sun from entring into it; the Coverlets of the Bed mut be very light, and the place round abound it may be prinkled with Oxycrate, made of one part of Vinegar, and ix of Roe-water, and the ret of the Chamber may be alo prinkled with common water, in which you may mix a little Vinegar too. Latly the Windows may be opened ome hours of the night to let in the cool refrehing blats.

On the contrary, during the extraordinary
colds of the Winter, you mut chooe a little Chamber, whoe Windows open to the South, and hut them very exactly in all places where the wind may enter; then ee that the Bed be not far from the Chimney, in which you mut be ure to keep a good fire day and night, remembring to cover your patient carefully; and, if it may be had, a skreen about the Bed, to keep it the warmer.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the Preparation of Bodies in which Mercury mut enter.

argument.p: 1. Confutation of the ordinary ways of preparing Bodies for the reception of Mercury. 2. That the true Method of preparing them cannot be perfectly decribed, but that a ufficient Idea may be given of it, for uch as have been Experienced. 3. Particular Preparation of Bodies of a good Contitution. 4. Means of correcting the Temperament of uch as are extremely Hot and Dry. 5. The manner of diminihing the extreme Repletion of thoe that are Cold and Phlegmatick.

div.p:
1. AMong thoe that employ Mercury for the procuration of the Cries of the Univeral Pox, ome prepare their Patients by Abtinence, Fumigations, Sudorificks, and drying Decoctions, for to conume the Phlegmatick humour, to which they pretend the Venereal Matter doth particularly adhere; others ue
Baths, Ptiannes, and whatoever is able to moyten and cool the Body, to facilitate the following Salivation hereby, and render the actions of Mercury the les pernicious; ome others ue partly things that moiten, and partly uch as dry; and others again make ue of Infinite different means, which I find to be all alike ridiculous, becaue they are ued indifferently to all perons, and they all differ only becaue each have found them practied on everal perons; whereas in truth the Age, Sex, Strength, Temperament, and generally the preent dipoitions of the everal Patients ought to contitute all the difference.

Indeed if it be by the means of Mercury alone that the Cries of the Univeral Pox are intended to be raied, there is no need of employing the other Remedies both Alterative and evacuative, before the application you would make of it, but only perhaps for the opening and dilatation of the paages that erve for Expulion of Excrements, in uch as are of a good Temper, or ele to correct the faults of thoe that are remote from this good Contitution. For if you hould offer to deiccate a Body that is
of a middle Age, moderate Temper, and that rightly performs all its natural Functions, 'tis certain it mut receive great Alteration, and this Alteration mut necearily remove it from the Equality and Moderation it was in before, which nevertheles is exactly the etate in which Nature keeps its true vgour, and in which conequently it mut be better able to econd the force of Remedies; whence it follows, that it comes to be les proper for the Critical motions which do follow the application of Mercury, in thoe in whom a ufficient quantity of acid Humours may be found, to top and detain the Mercury in the everal parts, for the time it ought to remain in them.

But if this Alteration can be o coniderably pernicious, even to uch as are in a tate of perfection; you will not at all wonder, if the Salivation cannot be afely procured in Dry, Cholerick, or Melancholick Bodies that have been prepared after this manner: nay, you will find on the contrary, that all the parts will receive injury from the activity of Mercury, eing it is now agitated by an extraordinary Heat, and finds nothing that is able to fix and detain it.

It is no les dangerous to make ue of things that cool and moiten, for the preparation of thoe that are replete and phlegmatick; for by this means the repletion is augmented, and the Humours become o dipoed for Fluxion, that Mercury oon draws them along with it in great abundance, and very often all the parts about the Throat do fill and well in uch manner, that the Patients are oon uffocated thereby.

But now peaking of the danger there is in making ue of the ame Remedies in all different Subjects, it comes into my mind, that I have read in a famous Author a certain Dipute that he raies and reolves himelf; 'tis whether thoe that have the Pox ought to be bled in their Preparation; he relates ome Authorities and Reaons Pro and Con, and at lat concludes in favour of Blood letting, of which he makes o general a Rule, that he will not except even uch as are Hectict: Whereupon you mut oberve, that this Maxim doth eem o much the more authentick, as it appears to be etablihed by a Learned Doctor, and founded on the examination and comparion of contrary Opinions; from
whence we may conclude that the faults which are committed by uch as blindly oberve it, are o much the more excuable, as they are often irreparable; ince there are a great many perons who never dare go a tep further than the Ideas of thoe that taught them. But I dare ay, it is a hameful thing, & diparages Phyick very much, that the greatet part of thoe who practie it, do apply themelves o little to things of uch moment; and that many who have by their own indutrry acquired ome particular knowledges, are o covetous and fearful of communicating them, that they affect to keep them ecret, even when they pretend to teach and dicover them. Let this be aid by the by.

2. Nevertheles you mut not imagin that infallible Rules can be given, for correcting exactly all the degrees of Temperaments, and everal dipoitions of all Bodies that are of different Contitutions. For beides that there are ome inward and ecret dipoitions, which can no way be known; the number of uch as may be known are in a manner infinite, and the endeavour I might here make for reckoning them up, would
caue nothing but confuion in this place. Notwithtanding it is certain, a ufficient Idea may be given of the Method that ought to be followed, for well preparing thoe that are infected with the Pox, by the dicovery of uch Remedies as may very happily erve to dipoe Bodies of a good Contitution, and correct the faults of uch as are extremely removed from this good etate by Repletion and Inanition; becaue thee patterns may erve to dicover the comparion of the Mean and two Extremes, from whence Formules may eaily be drawn for all the greater and leer degrees, by joyning a good Judgment, Application, and Experience (which are Qualities abolutely neceary for etablihing a ure practice) to the following Rules and Obervations.

3. You may caue a light Emotion in Bodies of a good Dipoition and middle Age, by ome gentle Purge; uch as may be an Infuion of two Drachms of Senna, mixt with an Ounce of new-drawn Caia, which will ufficiently open the way by iege, if you continue to repeat it four times, every Second day.
In the intermediate days you may Bathe your Patient morning and evening, to diolve the coagulated Humours, and dipoe the Pores of the Body for a dilatation.
During all this time you may make the following Ptianne erve for his ordinary Drink, which will open the Pores too, and alo the paages of Urine, that erve for expulion of Seroities.

Take half a Pint of good white Wine, in which infue and teep before-hand half an Ounce of Guaiacum; then take two Ounces of French Barley, four Quarts of common Water, and o much Licorice as may be ufficient for rendring your Ptianne pleaant enough to drink; in each Quart you mut mix ten or twelve Drops of the Spirit of Vitriol.
4. The faults which are oppoite to this good Temperament of which I now poke, are chiefly Inanition and Siccity, or ele Repletion and Humidity.

The former are the effects of a boyling Heat, and therefore require for Correctives, whatoever is capable of moitning and cooling at the ame time; whence it comes to pas that Blood-letting
which cools by allaying the Ebullition of the Blood, is notwithtanding dangerous and to be upected on this occaion, becaue it alo carries off the Humours, which are there already in too mall a quantity.

You may thence judge that Purges, and chiefly uch as are violent are alo dangerous; for beides that they conume the little Moiture which remains, they are extreme hot too; which are two Qualities abolutely contrary to the Intention you ought to have.

It will be good nevertheles to keep the Body open, by giving every morning half a Pint of Whey, in which you mut infue every fourth day, a Drachm of Senna, and half a Drachm of Crytal Mineral, to diolve in it afterwards half an Ounce of new-drawn Caia.

Seing Clyters that erve to cleane the Guts are able to caue ome Alteration, you mut have a care of giving them, unles it be a Decoction of cooling Potherbs, with two Ounces of Honey of white Lilies in each.
You mut Bathe him morning and evening for fifteen days together, and take care that the Bath be not hot enough to provoke Sweat.

You may prepare a Ptianne for his ordinary Drink with French-Barley, and the Roots of wild Succory, Sorrel and white Lilies, to which you may add ome Lycorice, and a little Lemmon, to render it more agreeable and cooling.

Broths and boil'd meat mut erve for his nourihment, which you mut diminih the quantity of by little and little; o that the Patient may find himelf inenibly reduced to the contant ue of liquid Aliments toward the end of his Preparation.
5. Exces of Repletion & Moiture is chiefly found in Bodies of a cold & Phlegmatick Temper, which you may correct by evacuating and drying them with the following Remedies.

You may frequently give them Clyters made of the Decoction of the Leaves of Mallows, Marh-mallows, and Mercury, the Flowers of Camomile and Melilot, Seeds of Anie and Fenugreek, adding to them Honey of Mercury.
You may here practie Blood-letting without any cruple, and repeat it everal times, if you judge the Plenitude of the Veels to be very coniderable.

An Infuion of three Drachms of Senna, one drachm of Agarick Trochicated, and as much of the Salt called Polychret, mixed with half an Ounce of the Confection Hamech, and an Ounce of Syrup of Peach flowers, will make up a Purge that may erve to evacuace abundance of Phlegm, if you repeat it even or eight times every econd day.
