You may prepare your Ptianne with two Quarts of ordinary Water, two Handfuls of French Barley, and three Ounces of Guaiacum, which you mut have teeped beforehand in a hot place with a Pint of white Wine, and you may render it fit and eaie to drink, by adding to the things aforeaid, a little Cinnamon Coriander-eed, Licorice, or Lemmon, according to the Tate and Palate of your Patient.

You may make him weat every evening, by giving him a good large Glas of the foreaid Ptianne to drink, in which you hall have dropt fifteen or twenty drops of the Spirit of Hartshorn; remembring to warm his Bed and Chamber as much as you can, and to put at the feet of uch as difficultly weat, Bottles filled with hot water. But if
thee things are not able to caue ome perons to weat, you will infallibly force them to weat ufficiently, by making them receive the Vapour of the Spirit of Wine in a certain Stove made on purpoe.

You mut diminih his Nourihment by degrees, as I have already told you in the former Preparation; only you may make thoe I now peak of fat with much les danger, than any others, and you mut prefer Rot-meat before Boiled, as being much more drying, becaue the Particles of Fire do act more directly upon it.

Beides the Middle Temperament and two Extremes, of which I have now poken, you will find many Bodies that require a les alteration, whether by Heat or Cold. In uch caes you mut ue Remedies of a more moderate trength; and for uch as are but indifferently Replete and Phlegmatick, you mut lay aide the trong Sudoriicks, and only ue the Decoctions of Saafras, China and Saraparilla, according as there is more or les neceity of drying. In like manner you may bath les thoe that are very hot and dry, or ele forbear the other cooling
Moitning Ptianne. Latly, for them all you mut be careful in augmenting or diminihing the trength of Purgatives and in general of all Remedies that erve for Preparation, according to the foreaid Coniderations.

div.head: CHAP. III. Of the different ways of making Mercury to enter into the Bodies of uch as are infected with the Pox.

argument.p: 1. General Diviion of the wayes, and that the practice of giving it by mouth is none of the best. The Preparations of Mercury that are given inwardly. 3. The different wayes of making it enter by the Pores of the Body; and firt of Plaiters that erve for this effect. 4. Of Ointments. 5. Of Troches for Fumigations.

div.p:
1. HAving let you ee after what manner you ought to prepare the Bodies in which you would have Mercury
to operate; it is now time to peak of the everal ways of uing it, and the choice that ought to be made of them according to the degrees of the Dieae, the upervening Accidents, and unhappy Circumtances, in which perons thus dieaed do ometimes find themelves.
Mercury is uually made enter into their bodies two manner of ways; either in at the Mouth, or ele univerally by the Pores.

It is worth oberving, before we proceed further, that the firt of thee ways is indeed none of the bet, becaue the Mercury that is thus taken at the Mouth, decends preently into the Stomach, whence it is uddenly Sublimated upwards by the Heat of this part; which caues the Salivation that is raied by this means to continue but a very little time, and not to terminate completely the univeral Pox, unles the Natural Heat be found trong enough to upply this defect by vigorouly following the Motion of Mercury.

I know well enough that ome perons do mix Purgatives with it, which do hinder its Sublimation, by precipitating it downwards. But this cutom eems to
have as little certainty as the former, becaue only paing through the Guts, it cannot purify at mot but that which is called the econd Region of the body; for there is no likelihood at all, that it hould be able to penetrate into the mot remote parts, to mix with all the Acid Humours that are there extravaated, and o draw them into the places I have poken of, by a contrary Motion.

By this way of arguing, and by the proof that I have made in this matter, and een others make too; I cannot but think, uch as indifferently practie this way of adminitring it, and make it pas for infallible in all that have the Pox, and in all the degrees of it, ought to be eteemed Ignorant, or Impotors; and Patients hould in all reaon rather rely upon the Honety and Experience of true Phyicians, who do find but too many Occaions for dicovering this truth, and are not wanting to advertie ingeniouly uch as have an unhappy inclination to run the hazard of a fale palliative Cure, becaue they have been once fally perwaded, or becaue they are engaged by particular Motives to earch out Remedies
they fancy more eay, and les troubleom. I do not mean but there may be found abundance of perons, who will maintain they have been cured by taking Mercury this way. But you mut oberve, that among them there are many who never had the Pox but only in their imagination; that in ome Nature did procure a Critical Motion of her own accord, near about the time they made this ue of Mercury; that in others he had been trongly moved to the ame effect, by the activity of other Remedies which have been mixed with it; latly that thoe who have ued it in the firt degree of this univeral Pox, that is to ay, when its matter remains till in the Veels, and hath not yet caued the ebullition of the blood, and conequently diffuion of eroities, might have been perfectly purified, by receiving through the rough Artery ome part of the Mercury that is ublimated from the Stomach up to the Mouth, and might by that means be carried to the Heart, from whence it becomes univerally pread through the Veels by the Circulation; or ele by attracting through the Lacteal Veines ome particles of that which is precipitated
downwards by the conjunction of Purgatives, out of which Veins it may be alo carried to the Heart, and thence dipered by the Motion of the blood, after the manner I now poke of.

2. Nevertheles if you will be deirous of trying to raie the Criis of the Pox after this manner, you had bet caue a loones with it, by mixing crude Mercury or weet Sublimate with purging powders, uch as Aloes, Colocynth, and prepared Scammony, which you may reduce into the conitance of Pills, of which you may give every day a Doe proportionable to the preent condition of your Patient.

You may alo provoke the Salivation, with thee two orts of Mercury, by incorporating as much as you can of the firt with Turpentine and the Crut of Bread dryed and powdred, to reduce it afterwards into the form of Pills, of which you may give from half a drachm to one drachm; or ele by mixing the econd from fifteen to thirty grains for each Doe in a little Conerve of Roes; remembring always that this lat ought to be preferred, and that the former is much more upicious, becaue it may reunite
it elf in the Stomach, or in the Guts, after the Turpentine is diolved.

Beides weet Sublimate, there are everal other Chymical Preparations of Mercury, that are pretended to be Purgative too, and do really Purge both by Vomit and Stool: Such as are red and white Precipitate, which are given from four to eight grains, and Turbith Mineral from three to ix. But you mut oberve that this effect doth principally proceed from the Corroion and Acutenes of corroive Salts, that hold Mercury under thee everal forms, and o the inward ue that is made of them is always to be accounted dangerous, unles you break the points of thee Acids before-hand, by burning more then once thee powders in the Spirit of Wine.

Almot all the Receipts, and pretended Secrets of Empyricks, and generally of uch as promie to Cure the Pox without obliging their Patients to quit their Employments for ome time, or any way changing their uual way of Living, do conit in the ue of the Powder of Algarot, and ome other Preparations of Antimony, which have no coniderable effect, beides that of poiling the Stomach
and diordering all the Natural Functions; or ele in the everal ways of giving Turbith Mineral, and the two Precipitates I now pake of. For ome of them give thee things imply, and without any other Preparation, in the Conerve of Roes; and pretend to make them pas quickly into all parts of the body, by giving preently afterwards to their Patients as much Wine as they are able to drink; on which ubject you mut oberve, that Wine taken in good quantity is mighty Diuretick, and that Mercury thus impregnated with Salts is eaily diolved, and carried off by Urine, which for that reaon then becomes very Salt and Acid, and is therefore the caue that there is but a very mall part of them that can enter or continue in the anguiferous Veels, and o very mall help can be expected from them. Others again give thee powders mixed with Gumme Gutta, the Reine of Jalap, and other Purgatives alike violent, which truly do preerve it in Motion, and do hinder it from adhering to the Stomach and Guts, but do often caue mot terrible Accidents by the fire that they enkindle in the body, and by the violence of the •• activity.
3. It remains then to make Mercury enter through the pores of the body, b • applying Mercurial Platers or Ointments upon it, and by reducing it into a Fumigation when mixed with reinous Drugs.

Mercurial Platers and Ointments are applyed to the ame places, and have very near the ame effect; the manner of uing them doth not differ neither, only the firt mut be pread upon Leather before they are applyed, whereas the latter are applyed directly upon the skin, which is afterwards only covered with ome Linnen.

That which is particular in this matter, is that the Mercury which enters into Platers requires a longer time to penetrate the Mas, than that which is put into Ointments, becaue it is more cloely confounded in the olidnes of the matter, and therefore you mut not change them but eldom or not at all, and cover from the beginning all the parts that ought to be covered.

The Plater which is ordinarily made ue of, is that which is decribed by, and called de Vigo, and is found prepared in all Shops, imple, double, or treble with Mercury. But for as much as it is of too
hard a conitence, and doth not eaily adhere to the skin, you may to better purpoe prepare another with eight ounces of Mercury, four ounces of Turpentine, and two pounds of the Plater of Mucilages.

4. That which is commonly called Emorbo, or the Grey Ointment, and by the Phyicians Neapolitan, is found prepared in Apothecaries Shops, and ome make the friction with it. But becaue the Doe of Mercury is very mall in it, and, becaue it is of an unavoury mell; you may prepare another, more effectual Oyntment, with four ounces of Mercury, two ounces of Turpentine, one ounce of the Oyl of Bays, two drachms of Saffron, and a pound and a half of the Ointment of Roes.
You may employ about two ounces of this Ointment for the firt friction, which you mut make from the Ankles till above the Knees, and from the Writs to the end of the Shoulder-blades.

Though this quantity of Mercury be eldom ufficient to bring Nature to a Critical Motion, nevertheles ome perons have been found o tender and delicate
or eay to put into this Motion, that they have received a Salivation even from the, very firt Friction, and in which perons a econd would have proved very dangerous; o that you mut oberve narrowly the Patient you undertake, o oon as you have thus given him Mercury, and you mut diligently examine whatoever happens to him anew, to the end you may preently leave of your Frictions, o oon as the igns of a Salivation do appear, and this to avoid Suffocation, which doth always happen, when the Humours are carried up to the Throat in too great an abundance.

In the econd Friction which mut be made four and twenty hours after the firt, you may employ up to four ounces of your Ointment, and rub the Legs and Thighs with it from the middle of the Foot to the upper part of the Hips, the Chine or Back-bone from the end of the Os Sacrum to the middle of the Neck, and the Arms, from the Writs again to the Shoulder-blades, not forgetting the places where the Glandules are eated, which erve for Emonctories to the Nobler parts.

This econd Friction is ometimes ufficient,
but we are often compelled to make a third too, with the ame Circumtances of the quantity of Ointment, and parts whereon it is applyed, which doth almot always produce the deired effect, when the body is rightly prepared as it ought to be.

But you mut not depair, though it hould fail to come yet; you mut then ue your bet prudence and dicretion, and have a care of going too fat in your intention, let Nature hould chance to urprize you on a udden. For Example, you mut let it alone for a day or two, before you begin a new Friction, and you mut employ but a mall quantity of your Ointment, if you perceive any appearance of Commotion. Be not obtinate neither in filling a body with Mercury by fifteen or twenty repeated Frictions, as ome Authors do unadviedly Counel, becaue it is a thing of very dangerous a conequence, and the Criis you mut deire hould rather depend on a good Preparation, than uch an abundance of this Medicament.

Howoever you'll find by Experience that a Doe of weet Sublimate will now prove wonderfully beneficial, if you give
it after a reaonable number of Frictions.

There remains omething till to be aid of the time and manner of performing them, becaue there are ome very ueful Circumtances which depend on them; For Example, in a Cold Seaon, it is needful to make choice of Noon, for the rubbing your Patients, becaue the Air of our Climate is then rendred a little more benign; and in hot Weather on the contrary you mut prefer the Mornings and Evenings, let the extraordinary Heat that is joyned with the Fire you mut make hould weaken them too much; but in mild Weather you may indifferently make ue of any hour of the Day, oberving only that the ditribution of Aliments be then finihed, that Nature may have no other Employment to take her off from conpiring together with the Mercury to raie the Criis you deire.

As for the manner of making this Friction, 'tis neceary to ay it mut always be made before the Fire, which mut be very great, but epecially in Winter, and encloed with a Skreen, or ome uch like thing, to hinder the Wind, and erve to reverberate the Heat, that the Mercury
may the better penetrate through the pores, and the Patient may not be moleted with any Cold; the Friction mut be repeated everal times on each part to facilitate this penetration.

5. Among the three ways of making Mercury enter through the pores, I have found by practice that the Fumigation is the wort of all, and is o much the more dangerous, as it is commonly performed by the Smoke of Artificial Cynabre, which may prove a kind of poion in its elf, but is thought to be corrected by the mixture of Sublimate Corroive, yellow Arenick, and other like Druggs, which are indeed poions much more pernicious.

Howoever I grant it may be ometimes preferred before the others, when the Pox comes to be in the lat degree of all, by reaon that the Mercury being thus turned into Vapours, doth penetrate the bones the better. But if you deire to draw the bet effect that can be expected from it, make ue of crude Mercury reduced into Troches with Turpentin, Coals made of Willow, and Orris powdered, and leave all the other Formules to uch as Ignorance doth engage to continue
in a certain road they dare not tir a tep out.

To conclude, there is nothing more common than the way of giving the Fumigation; a certain Couch is covered all round with a heet, and a little Stool turned upide downward is put under it, & upon it a Chaffendih of lighted Coals, in which Troches are burnt, whoe Vapour the Patient receives all naked under the Covering, always excepting the Head, which is only kept within from time to time, when there are Ulcers in the Noe, Mouth, or other parts of it.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Of the Critical Motions that are wont to be caued by Mercury.

argument.p: 1. That no Author hath ever yet explicated the Caues of thee different Motions, and the neceity there was of doing it. 2. Of the ways that erve for the Cries which are excited by Mercury, and how that by sweat comes to pas. 3. Of the Critical Evacuations that are made by Siege. 4. Of thoe that are made by Urine. 5. Of the Salivation. 6. Of the igns that do always demontrate a Salivation. 7. Remedies againt the Accidents that do commonly happen, and general Rules of the time it ought to lat.

div.p:
1. THere are ome Authors who have maintained, that Mercury applied exteriourly on the skin, doth act on the body only by an irradiative vertue, and that the Doe which was employed to this effect, might eaily be found again entirely in the Linnen and Platers, after provocation of the Criis;
others have endeavoured to prove on the contrary, that it penetrates the pores, that it acts on all the inward parts, and latly that it goes out o enibly with the Impurities of the body, that a piece of Copper may be whitened only by rubbing it a while in the Phlegm that runs out in the Salivation. But no body ever yet took the pains to enquire, why its Motions and Actions, and the Cries that reult from them do appear o very different, though it be prepared and given in the ame form and manner.

Thoe who have made ome Reflections on this ubject, are contented to admire this Mineral, and conider it as an Hydra with many Heads, or as the Proteus of Phyick; they have pretended that there was ome Analogie between it and the Mercury of Atrologers, which produces different effects according to its different Conjunctions with other Planets; without taking notice of nevertheles, or preuming to teach us, what are thoe matters it uually joyns with, for to act o differently. They have made indeed many Elogiums of its vertues, without offering to give any explication of its effects; Latly they have
told us that no Drug in all the Medicinal matter is fit to erve for a Subtitute in its place, but have never dicovered to us any reaon of its ingular qualities, or what's the matter that thoe who have employed it have only acted like blind-men in it; o that young Students who have turned over all manner of Books for ome illutration of this matter, have never been able to find any atisfaction, but have till been compelled (as others have) to remain in their former obcurity; and Patients who have been urpried with Events contrary to what they were made expect, have found no perons capable of building the comfort they give them on ufficient or olid Reaons.

Nevertheles the explication of thee things was not really o difficult; Men might have made comparion between the Principles of Art and thoe of Nature, and between things Artificial in Mechanicks, and epecially in Chymitry, with what paes Naturally in the bodies wherein Mercury doth enter. The Obervations which I have made on this ubject, and which every body might have made as well as I, may perhaps prove ufficient for the Evidence of what
was hitherto hid, being alo joyned with the Applications of them, perons may make themelves. In a word, the many Experiments and Events would clearly have dicovered the truth, if men had been but curious enough to eek it out.

But whether it be that the knowledge of it was not judged neceary, or that no body was willing to take the pains of acquiring it, or ele that thoe who poeed the knowledge of it were not willing to communicate what they knew; it is very certain that no Author hath yet undertook to teach it, and yet I cannot conceive, how the Artificial Cries of the Pox can be perfectly explicated, without letting ee at the ame time what it is that renders them o different.

2. The ways through which the Venereal matter doth ordinarily pas in thee orts of Cries, are either uch as erve for Sweat, or for paage of the Urine, or expulion of the groer Excrements, or epecially thoe that erve for the Salivation.

The Criis that is made through the firt of thee ways doth happen, when the Mercury finds a great many Sulphurous Vapours which do erve for the matter of fat, in bodies wherein it enters; for as
it doth ever mix willingly with Sulphurs, and is already dipoed to it by the diviion that hath been made of it with Reinous bodies, it doth eaily unite with fat and vaporous matters, which render it more light, more volatil, and conequently more fit to follow their Motion from the Center to the Circumference. But as this ame Motion is in ome manner contrary to the penetration which Mercury ought to make for ufficiently purifying the blood; it often happens that this Criis is but imperfect, unles Nature her elf be that way exceedingly dipoed.

3. Some bodies are found to be o filled with a Tartarous Salt, or other matters of the Nature of Alkalis, that the Mercury which enters into them precipitates downwards by their means, and the Impurities are carried off by Siege. But as thee matters do not hinder the Mercury from-penetrating into all the parts, this Criis is much more certain than the former, epecially when the Phyician helps Nature to act, by often-repeated Purges and Diureticks.

4. That which caues the Mercury and Venereal Salts to be ometimes carried
off by Urine, is that Acids are found in ome bodies, near in as great a Number as Alkalis is in others: The truth of this Opinion may be eaily proved; for every body knows that Acids taken inwardly become Diuretick, and the Obervations upon Mercury do hew, that they may be ublimated by Heat, when joyned with it, and that they can be precipitated by Alkalis, even after this Sublimation. Now you may perceive by what I have aid, that the property of Acids is to carry off Phlegm and Seroities by way of Urine, but that they are not able to produce this effect, when joyned with Mercury, and agitated by the Natural Heat, unles Alkalis do alo ufficiently abound, to precipitate it downwards. Furthermore eeing impure Salts are eaily diolved in watry ubtances, and this Criis hath very much affinity with that which is made by Salivation, I conceive it mut be more perfect than the other two, when its Evacuations continue long and large enough.

5. As 'tis the property of Leaven to extend it elf in the things that ferment, and render them hereby of a like Nature, o the Venereal Salts do diolve in the
blood, extend themelves into all parts of the body, and render by this means almot all the Humours harp and Acid. This is the reaon why the Salivation is the mot ordinary Criis of the Pox, that is provoked by the help of Mercury, becaue it charges it elf with thee Acid Liquours in o great a meaure, that nothing is able to carry it off o well by the other ways I mentioned; And it is this which may be eteemed the uret of all to cure this Dieae; for beides that it is very eldom een to fail, when well managed, the Circumtances which do accompany it make us judge the better of its goodnes. It is remarkable in the firt place, that its Motion is from below upwards, and is commonly equal, moderate, and without any interruption, which hews that Nature acts rather of her own accord, than by the meer force of the Remedy. Moreover all the Acid and impure Humours do acend o eniby with the Mercury, that this mixture is near of the ame quality with the diolution of this Mineral in the Spirit of Niter, or Aqua fortis, in o much that being driven up by the Heat, there is made a kind of Sublimate Corroive which exulcerates all
the parts of the Throat and Mouth, and penetrates them o exceedingly, that their Veels are opened, and blood runs out of them for ome days, until the matter becomes les acrimonious by a maller quantity of Acids.

Impotors who give the Salivation to uch as have not the Pox, make thee Ulcers pas for effects of the Malignity of Venereal Salts that they may the better conceal their Villanies by uch perwaions. But you mut oberve, that they do indeed happen as well to uch as have not the Pox, as thoe who really have it, becaue they are produced by the mixture I lately poke of, or by reaon that there are Acid Juyces in all Men generally; in a word becaue the Mercury is oon ublimated, paes quickly, and doth but lightly heat the Mouth in thoe who have too few Acids to govern its Motion, unles the other matters which I have poken of do train or draw it ome other ways: So that the Ulcers of the Mouth and Throat ought to be conidered as ineparable Accidents of this Criis, whatoever Indipoitions it may be intended for.

6. Moreover you may know it in its
beginning by the agitation of the Pule, the inquietudes of Mind and Body, the diminution or entire los of appetite, by the retiring of the Eyes, heat of Mouth, welling of the Gums and Lips, thicknes of the Tongue, tink of Breath, pain of Teeth, whitenes of the Palate, and interruption of leep.

When you hall find the Criis to approach by all thee Signs, you mut forbear your Frictions, Fumigations, and generally all Mercurial Remedies, to avoid Suffocation and other accidents which Mercury doth caue, when given in too great a quantity. But if its application hath been reaonably well performed in a Body rightly prepared, there will ucceed to the Signs I named a continual trickling of white phlegm in a long thread, which will at firt run but gently, but will augment by degrees for nine days time; o that the more Phlegmatick perons may be able thus to pit up to eight pounds in four and twenty hours, and others in proportion.

In the firt days of the ublimation of Mercury, the Belly receives ome commotion from its paage, and this caues a Flux downwards, which lats indeed
but a mall time, and requires no particular conideration. It may be alo oberved in the increae of the Salivation, that the Ulcers which I poke of do enlarge in latitude and profundity by the action of the matter that runs out of them; and that the motion of the Artery appears almot as trong and unequal, as in burning Fevers, becaue impurities cannot be thus eperated from the Blood, without raiing a great Ebullition in it, by the motion of Mercury, or trength of the natural heat. But eeing thee things do happen through an indipenible, neceity, and are not at all contrary to what may fairly be expected from the Action of Mercury, you need not trouble your elves to think of preventing or curing them by contrary Remedies.

7. Nevertheles you may mitigate the pains in the Belly, when they become very hard to endure, by the means of Anodyne and cooling Clyters; or ele diminih the corroding Acrimony, which caues Ulcers in the Mouth, with gentle affwaging Gargarims; uch as are, for example, Cows Milk luke-warm, or the Decoction of French-Barley, Lineed,
and Fleawort-eed; to which mut be added, that it is ometimes neceary to conume the corrupted fleh about them with Spirits of Wine, Vitriol, or Sulphur.

It hould remain to ay omething of the Quantity of the Matter, and time of its running; but eeing thee two Circumtances do abolutely depend on the Temperaments of perons, and degrees of the Dieae, they cannot be preciely regulated, but by the Judgment, Application and Experience of him that treats them. Wherefore I hall not detain you to no purpoe on this Subject, but believe it may uffice to ay generally peaking, that you ought not to begin counting the days of the Flux, until it is able to furnih at leat two pounds of Matter in four and twenty hours, and that it ought to continue a fortnight at leat, and a month at mot.

Nevertheles there are ome Authors who pretend that the ceation of Accidents, and epecially of the Flux, are undoubted marks of a complete and perfect Cure. But you may eaily perceive this Rule not to be infallible, ince I have proved in another place, that the
Caue of the Pox may till remain, when the ordinary Accidents are vanihed away; and that there are other Accidents on the contrary, which can never wholly diappear, but by the application of particular Remedies, either during, or after the univeral Purification of the Body; for example, the Rottennes of Bones, which mut be corrected by actual Cauteres; the Conumption of Fleh or Skin made by Tetters or profound Ulcers, which can never be regenerated but by mundifying Medicines; latly the Relaxation and weaknes of the Spermatick Veels, which caues in ome perons a continual Effluxion of the Seed, until they be cloed up again by typtick and atringent Remedies. Beides you will find by experience, that the Flux often ceaes before the Dieae, and that it is ometimes neceary to renew it; or at leat to ait the former Evacuation with Remedies that purge through other paages, epecially when Nature is o inclined.

But you mut not do like thoe who think they can never enough drain the Bodies that are thus infected, who conume and exhaut the Radical Moiture
it elf, which is the foundation of Life, after having drawn away all the other Humours. But remember rather, that it is of as great importance to preerve what is natural to the Body, as to detroy whatoever is enemy to or againt Nature. And to the end you may the better avoid this Exces, you mut oberve very exactly, how far the Body is dried, how the forces are pent, and all the other Circumtances, which I gave you before; that o you may timely top the Salivation after a ufficient continuance of it, by change of Linnen, Bed, and ometimes Chamber too, or by the Precipitation of Mercury, which may be made with the Salt of Tartar taken alone in a Broth, or mixed with the ordinary Purges and Diureticks.

div.head: CHAP. V. Of the Diet of uch as are in the Artificial Cries of the Pox.

argument.p: 1. In what this Diet doth conit in general, and why it is neceary to give particular examples of it. 2. The manner of governing thoe who are of a good Complexion: 3. Who are Hot and Dry: 4. Who are Cold and Moit. 5. General Obervations for them all.

div.p: 1. THE Method of governing uch as are in the Cries that are raied by Mercury, doth in general conit in preerving them from the violence of ill Air and bad Weather, in regulating the Quality and Quantity of Aliments and Medicaments, and if you will alo, in a Moderation of the Paions of the Mind.

The means of anwering the firt point have been already given, when I poke of the proper eaons to treat the Pox; and it eems that the prudence and dicretion of the Phyician ought to make
Rules for the other two. Nevertheles eing it is often impoible to correct perfectly in the Preparation, all the preternatural Dipoitions which proceed from the divere Temperaments of perons, and it is conequently neceary to perit until the end of the Cure, in a regular ue of things that are contrary to their pernicious Qualities; it may be expedient to do as I have here done in delivering the Method of Preparing uch as have this Dieae, that is to ay, of hewing here the proper management of Nourihment and Remedies for uch as are of an even and good Temperament, and for thoe that are removed from this good Mean, by great Repletion and Inanition; after which you will here find ome general Circumtances it is convenient to oberve, in all thoe perons who are treated with Mercury.

2. There are two Rules particularly important for the Diet of one of a middle Temper; the firt is, Not to give him any more Aliments than will preerve his forces in good plight, that Excrements and Superfluities may not too much abound: and the econd is, That you give him light Remedies for to open
the chief paages, that Nature may not be diverted in her operations by contrary motions.

You will ufficiently anwer the firt Rule, if you give him two new-laid Eggs at noon, and a Broth every fourth hour, all the ret of the day and night, which you may make with a Leg of Beef, Pullets and ome Succory.

The Ptianne which I have before decribed for preparation of Bodies of this conitence, may alo erve them very well during the Criis, to anwer the econd Rule I gave you; becaue it is Sudorifick and Diuretick, and may be alo rendred proper for gently looning the Body, by making a cold Infuion of two Drachms of Senna four and twenty hours in a Quart of it, which you may make him drink every econd day at everal draughts.

3. When you hall come to treat a Body that is very Hot and Dry, you mut remember it would be a dangerous thing to nourih him too little, or give him Aliments of a Heating quality. Wherefore you mut prefer Broths before new-laid Eggs, and give him one at leat every third hour, made of a Leg of Veal,
Beef and Pullet, adding to it in Summer Sorrel, Lettice and Purlain, or in Winter Succory. But if your Patient naueates this kind of Nourihment, you may make him a Gelly with the above-mention'd meats, French-Barley, a little of the cold Seeds and Sugar.

You may afely make ue of the moitning and cooling Ptianne, which I decribed when I poke of the means of preparing thee perons; in a Quart of which you may infue a Drachm of Senna, and o much Crytal Mineral to give him every fourth day.
Clyters that cool and moiten the Body will prove very effectual, if you make them of Whey, or a Decoction of Potherbs, mixing with each an Ounce of Honey of Violets or white Lilies.

4. On the contrary, during the time you treat a Body that is extreme Phlegmatick and replete, you mut not be contented only with the Critical Evacuations that are commonly made by the Mouth; but you mut endeavour al manner of ways beides to exhaut his Humours; o that ome Broths or new-laid Eggs given every ix hours will uffice for his Nourihment, becaue you mut give
him but only jut enough to keep him alive.
The Ptianne made of Guaiacum will alo erve to dry him the more, if you prepare it according to the Doe I mentioned in the Chapter of the Preparation.
You may often give Clyters made of common Honey, and a Decoction of the Leaves of Sage, Wormwood, Rue and Fennil.

You may prepare laxative Potions, whoe ue mut be frequent, with a Decoction of Sage-leaves, an Infuion of Senna and Hermodactyls, and the Syrup of Roes or Peach-flowers; taking care of giving them to uch a Doe, as may not be apt to divert the Salivation in its beginning, or diminih it when it is in its vigour.

5. By the Examples I have given you, and by what hath been already aid in delivering the means of preparing Bodies for the Motions and effects of Mercury, you will eaily frame different Methods, for uch as are in the everal degrees of more or les; and there is no neceity of precribing any others more particularly on this Subject. But it is o much
the more neceary here to remark the following Obervations, as they ought in general to erve for all thoe who are in any Criis that follows the application of this Remedy.
In all fainting and wooning fits you may prefer a little Wine before Cordial Liquours, or Acid Fruits, and you will find by experience that it hath a better Effect.
You mut forbear Biscakes, Comfits, and generally all weet ugar'd things, becaue they make the Teeth black, and increae the acrimony and pain which they do then uffer in the Throat.

After the Evacuations have been ufficient, and you have topt the Flux, or hinder'd the others, you mut draw your Patients by little and little, out of the great weaknes they then ubit in, by a gradual augmentation of their nourihment, after the ame manner as you diminih'd it in their Preparation; remembring always that you cannot uddenly change them out of Inanition into Repletion, without endangering their Suffocation, or putting them into ome deperate and mortal Dieae.

So oon as they hall be re-etablihed a
little by this means, you may reaume the ue of Purgatives, Diureticks and Sudorificks, to et Nature at work again, and help to drive out uch Impurities as do ometimes till remain after all thee former endeavours.

Moreover the Tranquility of the Mind is o neceary during all the Cure, that there is always a great deal of danger, where it is wanting, and conequently it is your Duty to remove from your Patients all things which may tir up the Paions of the Mind, and epecially Fear, Sadnes, Anger, care of any buines of concernment, or any kind of particular application of the Mind; o that you mut always be ure to entertain them with the hopes of a afe and happy Cure, you mut relate to them only things which may pleae and rejoyce their hearts, and you mut give them all manner of atisfaction as far as you are able; or at leat pleaantly repreent to them the prejudice they would be apt to uffer from things which cannot be granted to them without danger. Nay, you mut alo take care of their affairs, where there is occaion, either really or ele in hews; Latly, you mut take away
from them all Books, Manucripts, and generally all uch things as are capable of engaging them in two much thoughtfulnes, epecially after that Mercury is once applied.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Of the particular Circumtances that ought to be oberved for treating Methodically Women and little Infants.

argument.p: 1. Neceary obervations for the treating of Women. 2. That Infants are uceptible of the Pox at all times, but that there is no neceity of giving different Methods for all degrees of Youth. 3. The manner how to treat the mallet Infants, and a Precept of moment on this Subject.

div.p:
1. Whatoever hath been hitherto aid concerning the way of curing the Pox, may equally erve for both Sexes, as well as alo for all Ages, if you do but proportionate your Remedies
to the trength of your Patient. Only there are indeed ome particular Circumtances it is neceary to oberve, for the better curing of Women, and little Children. For if the firt of thee perons have their Terms uppret, you mut in the firt place of all labour to provoke them, while you are in their Preparation for the reception of Mercury, becaue you mut always make the application of it, o oon as, or preently after they have ufficiently flowed, for fear let if they hould renew their Coure too oon, they might create a great diorder in the Oeconomy of Nature, by a contrary motion to that of the Salivation.

You mut alo take notice that there ometimes happen very urgent Accidents which engage them to be treated while they are with Child; and you will find by experience that they can then undergo the Cure without danger, by oberving to manage them gently, and epecially to chooe a time wherein their grones is a little advanced; becaue the Infant is too weak in its beginning, to reit the diturbance which Mercury and the other Remedies do caue in the Body, and becaue it might be apt to accelerate
celerate the Child-bed toward the end, before the Off pring doth receive a perfect maturity.

2. Infants are capable of catching the Pox, either in the Womb of their Mother, or by ucking dieaed Nures; in a word, by being kied or toucht everal wayes by perons infected with this Dieae. Whence it comes to pas, that it may happen in all the times and degrees of Youth, and o conequently cannot be treated after the ame manner, ince the tripling that ucks his nourihment from the Teat, is infinitely les fit to bear the violence of Remedies, than he that is able to live like other men, by advancement of years.

Notwithtanding there is no neceity of giving different Methods for all Ages, becaue the many various Intentions, Repects and Remedies, which I have already mentioned, may alo erve for the Cure of Infants, only oberving a due proportion of them to their mall condition. But it is needful nevertheles to precribe the particular Method of curing well the mallet of all; that o having examples before you of the greatet and leat, you may the more eaily judge
of the quality and quantity of things which ought to be employed in the different degrees of mediocrity.

3. So oon as you hall have dicover'd the Pox in an Infant that ucks, you mut firt of all endeavour to dicover the peron that did communicate it, to the end you may remove uch peron before you entreprie any thing. After which you mut chooe a good Nure, to contribute towards the purification of his blood by the ue of wholom Milk, which you mut carefully preerve in all its purity by precribing her a good Dyet, and eparating your little Patient from her; and you mut give him Milk only with a little poon, or ele with fine Linnen, that he may uck after 'tis dipt in it. But you mut know that the Milk of a Goat well fed is infinitely to be preferred before that of an unound Woman.
It will be neceary to purge him in the beginning of all with a little Water of Caia, or the Syrup of Roes, and repeat this Purge everal times, according as he is more or les replete.

You may prepare a Ptianne for him with a handful of French-Barley, and three or four drachms of China-root,
which you may boil in three Quarts of common Water, to the diminution of the third part, adding to it toward the end a little Licorice, & after you have pased it ten grains of Crytal Mineral, for to give him to drink or uck of, from time to time day and night.
After having opened by this means the common paages of the Excrements, you may rub the bottom of his Feet every third day with a drachm of the following Ointment;

Take a drachm or a drachm and a half of Mercury revived from Cynnabre, and kill it in two ounces of the Balom of Arceus, adding afterwards ix ounces of Hogs-greae well wahed, and make ue of it ix or eight times the way I have told you.

If thee firt Frictions don't procure a Flux, or do caue ome other ort of Criis, you mut even continue them without other Mytery as long as they hall be thought neceary; or ele you may make them tronger by the augmentation of the Doe of the fore-aid Ointment, with half a drachm, or more for each Friction, and by employing it partly on the Feet, and partly on the hands.

During the time of the Critical Evacuations, you may give him every ix days two or three grains of the volatil Salt of Vipers, diolved in a little of the Tianne decribed before; and you may prefer this ame Remedy before all the Treacle, Philoophical, and Sudorifick Waters, from whence ome Authors do promie uch fale wonders.

Now the mot important precept I have to give you on the account of little Infants, is to treat them as gently as they have but little trength, and to pare neither time nor pains to encreae their mall trength, or at leat to preerve it; for if you weaken them by the force of your Remedies, you'll mierably drive them into an inevitable death, intead of curing them as you deigned; eeing the Operation of Medicaments is always either dangerous, or unueful, if it be not econded by the efforts of Nature.

div.head: CHAP. VII. Of the Misfortunes which may follow the Application of Mercury.

argument.p: 1. The Caues of the Death of ome that are infected with the Pox, and the Caues of the Accidents which ometimes happen after the Application of Mercury. 2. What are thoe Accidents. 3. General Remedies that erve to put a top to their Violence. 4. Particular Remedies for the Cure of them.

div.p: 1. THough the Pox be not a Dieae mortal of it elf, and I hold it curable in all its degrees, it is true nevertheles that Men may dye of it (as I have aid before) when its matter hath corrupted or detroyed the parts without which there is no living; when one infected with it hath fallen into the unhappy practices of Ignorants and Impotors: Latly when careles Phyicians do not oon enough remedy the Accidents which ometimes happen after the Application of Mercury.

Not but the precepts which I have given are almot infallible, for curing this Dieae uddenly, eaily, and urely, and hardly can they fail in one of a thouand, when they are regularly oberved. But there are ome dimal Circumtances, which it is impoible to remove. For beides that Men are necearily mortal, the true Caue of their Death is often unknown, the time of it cannot be avoided, and the Cacochymie of bodies is now & then o very great, that it cannot poibly receive Correction; to which may be added that there are ome inward Dipoitions, which can no way be known, or there is no poibility of taking away. Whence it comes to pas, that the ucces of this undertaking is not always o happy as we could wih, and Accidents may indeed happen which could in no wie be expected, to which nevertheles we ought to adhibite Remedies with all manner of care and exactnes, which are things greatly neceary in all Occaions where Life and Death are concerned.

2. Now though all thee Caues are of the ame conequence, it would be but a vain attempt to deliver the means of detroying them all, ince that ome of them
cannot be known, and others cannot poibly be removed. It may be ufficient to ay omething of the ill Tempers of Bodies, and the too great quantity of Mercury which may be made enter into them, becaue they are the uual Caues of all the Accidents which follow its application, and there are none but may happen by reaon of them. For when all the things that cool and moiten have been ued to no purpoe for quenching the Fire, and correcting the drynes of an extraordinary Melancholick body, there is often found to follow a loones accompanied with unufferable gripes & pains, and which oon leaves a contipation behind, that caues an Inflammation of the Entrals, Bret, Throat, and Mouth, with difficulty of Breathing, Swallowing, and Speaking; which Symptoms oon begin a Fever, that in a mall time becomes violent enough, to ublimate the Mercury up to the Brain, and thereby caue Swoonings, Phrenies, Convulions, and very often Deafnes, and Blindnes, Apoplexies, and Palies, or latly Death it elf, if care be not uddenly taken to prevent it, by due applying fit Remedies againt this train of misfortunes.

In like manner if the Dyet, drying Decoctions, and trong Sudorificks have not been ued ufficiently to make a convenient alteration of a very Phlegmatick and replete body, or ele if Mercury hath been applyed in too much hat, it will ublimate along with it all on a udden, o great a confluence of Humours that the mot part of the Accidents I now reckoned up will alo appear, but more particularly an extraordinary Swelling of the Throat, Tongue, Cheeks, and often of all the whole Face, with coniderable hardnes, and loones of Teeth, and with an immoderate Flux of Blood from the Ulcers of the Mouth, which in a hort time become great, preading, black, tinking, and gangren'd, and which do at lat caue Death, if a Suffocation don't prevent their malignancy.

3. In all thee mierable Conjunctures the bet means to be ued do conit in hindring the Activity of Mercury, in the diminution of its quantity by change of Bed, Linnen, and Chamber, and in the precipitation of the ret downwards by atringent Gargarims, Clyters, Phlebotomies in the Foot, and epecially by often repeated Purges, in which you mut
be ure always to mix the Salt of Tartar, proportionating the ret of the Ingredients to the Age, Strength, and Temperament of your Patients.

Some do make ue of a Golden Pill, which they caue to be wallowed everal times after as many Lotions, and which always indeed carries off ome very little Mercury on its Superficies; but it is o very mall a quantity for o long a time, that no great effect can be expected from it, and its ue mut by no means hinder that of the former Remedies.

4. After having thus provided againt all thee Accidents in general, by the means that I have propoed; 'tis time to think of uch as demand particular Correctives, and apply Cupping-glaes with carifications on the nape of the neck, or on the houlders, for all Phrenies, Convulions, Apoplexies, Deafnes, Blindnes, and in general for all Indipoitions of the Brain and Nerves.

A Gargarim made with a Decoction of Plantain, red Roes, and Agrimony in which you mut drop a little Spirit of Vitriol, will prove atringent enough to repel the Blood or Phlegm that runs out of the Mouth, and deterive enough to
cleane the Ulcers which hall be toucht from time to time with the Chymical Spirits before named.
It is obervable, that this ame Gargarim may alo erve to trengthen the looe Teeth, by cloing of the Gums, which nevertheles may be much better fatned by touching them with the Aqua ecunda.
An Oxyrrhodin made of one part of Vinegar, and two of Oyl of Roes, outwardly applyed on the Throat, awages it, takes down the Swelling, and diminihes the Inflammation.
You may alo for the ame effect make ue of the Cere-cloth of Galen, mixt with the Oyl of weet Almonds.

A few poonfuls of good Wine will do a great deal of good in all Faintings, and Swoonings, for to fortifie the Heart, and dipere again the uffocated Spirits, which you mut prefer in this occaion, before all the Confections, Cordial Potions, and other artificial Cardiacks.

Cows-Milk luke-warm will wonderfully appeae the pains in the Guts, if you make Fomentations of it outwardly and Injections within, in which you may add ome Yelks of Eggs, and ome grains of
Laudanum, to render them yet more Anodyne.

Beides thee Ordinary Remedies, the knowledge which you ought to have of things that appertain to Phyick, the Intructions which you may learn, and the Counel you may pleae to take, will furnih you with an infinity of others on particular Occaions.
